But, as I learned that chilly Seattle fall, Biff’s sound judgment disappeared at quickly as the scotches – and was replaced by a foolish desire to drive drunk.
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_posts/2018-11-05-save-the-souse.md-18-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_posts/2018-11-05-save-the-souse.md:19:As an engineer, or perhaps as a foreshadowing of my future role as development lead, I'd devised a structural solution. When we went to parties, Biff got to drive us there, then I'd take his keys, savor my one and only one IPA and then be in charge of getting us home. The buddy system had thus far proven to be 100 proof effective.
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_posts/2018-11-05-save-the-souse.md-20-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_posts/2018-11-05-save-the-souse.md-21-However, one day as we arrived at a party, I was distracted by a redhead and made a beeline to bask in her presence. Thirty minutes later, I had come to see two things: the redhead had no interest in me and Biff had already seen the bottom of four scotch glasses.

/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/caring.md-9----
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/caring.md-10-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/caring.md:11:Let's define caring, as the intensity of our emotions, critical given a lack of emotional intensity is depression. Intense emotions are synonymous with interest and mental energy, which is a double edged sword: Good caring (commitment to our identity, positive habits) charges us up, but bad caring (attachment, anger, anxiety, focus on things we don't control), brings us down. When bad caring manifests as repetitive, ruminating thought patterns, they become psychic shadows requiring specialized techniques:
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/caring.md-12-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/caring.md:13:{%include summarize-page.html src="/psychic-shadows" %}

/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md:3:title: "Psychic Shadows: Crafting Spells to Banish Ruminating Thoughts"
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-4-tags:

/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-15-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md:16:It's 3am and your brain is replaying that conversation from six months ago, calculating worst-case financial scenarios, or imagining all the ways you'll fail at that thing you haven't even started yet. These aren't just ordinary worries - they're psychic shadows, specific thought patterns that loop endlessly in your mind like restless spirits. If you're tired of being held hostage by these ruminating thoughts, this post will teach you how to craft personalized spells that banish each shadow the moment it appears, giving you a mystical toolkit for transforming persistent mental loops into single-word circuit breakers that actually work.

/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-18-{% include blob_image_float_right.html src="blog/racoon-power-word.webp" %}

/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-41-<!-- prettier-ignore-end -->
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-42-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md:43:## The Nature of Shadows
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-44-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md:45:Psychic shadows are different beasts than the general [mind monsters](/mind-monsters) or broader [psychic weight](/psychic-weight) we carry. While mind monsters are emotional states like anger or pride, and psychic weight encompasses all the mental burden we bear, shadows are specific thought loops that follow predictable patterns:
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-46-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-47-**They're precise and specific**: Not "I'm worried about money" but "What if the market tanks and I lose everything during my gap year?" Not "I'm concerned about health" but "What if I get lazy without work structure and lose all my physical discipline?"
--
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-49-**They're repetitive and sticky**: The same thought returns again and again, often triggered by specific situations or even random moments of mental quiet.
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-50-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md:51:**They demand rumination**: Unlike passing worries, shadows insist you think them through completely, analyze every angle, plan for every contingency - even though this mental work rarely provides relief.
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-52-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md:53:From my own [psychic weight](/psychic-weight) catalog, here are shadows I've wrestled with:
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-54-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md:55:- The bathroom remodel shadow: "The contractor is trying to screw us over" - a thought that kept me awake for days, cycling through evidence and counter-arguments
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md:56:- The money insecurity shadow: "I can't spend money on the larger milk because it's more expensive per ounce" - even when I was spending $100 on bar tabs
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md:57:- The work document shadow: "If I don't finish this perfectly, everyone will think I'm incompetent" - leading to endless revisions and procrastination
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-58-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md:59:Each shadow has its own signature pattern, its own trigger points, its own way of hijacking your mental resources.
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-60-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-61-## The Art of Spell-Crafting
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-62-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md:63:The ancient practice of spell-crafting isn't about magic wands and cauldrons - it's about conscious intention channeled through precise words. When you craft a spell for a psychic shadow, you're creating a circuit-breaker for rumination, a way to interrupt the thought loop and redirect your mental energy.
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-64-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md:65:### Step 1: Catch the Shadow
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-66-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md:67:Before you can banish a shadow, you must first see it clearly. This requires developing what I call "shadow awareness" - the ability to notice when you've slipped into a rumination loop.
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-68-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md:69:But here's the crucial distinction: not all mental discomfort deserves banishment. Some thoughts are **functional mental pain** - friendly spirits that deserve attention because they're pointing to something that actually needs your focus. Others are **mental suffering** - the unhelpful meanings and stories we add on top, creating shadows that need banishment.
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-70-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-71-{% include summarize-page.html src="/mental-pain" %}
--
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-77-- "I feel disappointed about my performance" → Points to skills that need development
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-78-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md:79:**Mental suffering (shadows to banish)**:
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-80-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-81-- "I always mess everything up" → Unhelpful story about your identity
--
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-87-But before crafting a spell, ask: **Is this pain pointing to something that actually needs my attention, or is this suffering I'm adding on top?** Functional pain deserves action. Mental suffering deserves banishment.
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-88-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md:89:Practice this meta-cognition. Label it: "This discomfort I'm experiencing is shadow rumination" - but only after confirming it's not a friendly spirit with a legitimate message.
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-90-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-91-### Step 2: Analyze Deeply
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-92-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md:93:This is where the real work happens, and it's where the [anxiety management](/anxiety-management) framework becomes crucial. You can't just suppress the shadow - you need to understand what it's really about.
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-94-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-95-{% include summarize-page.html src="/anxiety-management" %}
--
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-97-Apply the anxiety management process:
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-98-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md:99:**Identify the precise threat**: What exactly is the shadow warning you about? Strip away the exaggeration and catastrophizing. Get specific.
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-100-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-101-**Generate realistic probabilities**: What are the chances this feared outcome actually happens? What are the more likely scenarios?
--
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-109-### Step 3: Bind to Word
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-110-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md:111:Now comes the mystical part. Take all that analysis, all that understanding, and distill it into a single word or short phrase. This word becomes your spell - a compressed version of your deeper wisdom that you can deploy instantly when the shadow appears.
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-112-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md:113:The word should feel powerful to you, should resonate with the antidote to your specific shadow. Some examples:
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-114-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md:115:- **"Abundance"** - for shadows about scarcity and loss
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md:116:- **"Capable"** - for shadows about competence and failure
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md:117:- **"Present"** - for shadows about future catastrophes
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md:118:- **"Worthy"** - for shadows about rejection and abandonment
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md:119:- **"Flow"** - for shadows about control and rigidity
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-120-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-121-The key is that the word should immediately connect you back to your deeper analysis, like a bookmark to your wisdom.
--
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-123-### Step 4: Deploy the Spell
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-124-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md:125:When you catch the shadow starting its familiar dance, speak your spell word. Say it out loud if possible, or with clear intention in your mind.
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-126-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-127-**Important limitation**: Spells can only be so powerful. You can't simply make yourself stop thinking about something - try not to think about a pink elephant on a giant ball right now, and you'll see what I mean. The mind doesn't work through suppression. Instead, spells work by **redirecting your attention to something else**. Your spell word should connect you to a different thought, feeling, or action.
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-128-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md:129:This is why it's crucial to pair spell-work with activities you genuinely enjoy. Be wary of using addictive distractions (endless scrolling, substances, compulsive behaviors) to avoid shadows - these create new problems.
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-130-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-131-{% include summarize-page.html src="/addiction" %}
--
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-135-{% include summarize-page.html src="/todo_enjoy" %}
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md-136-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/psychic-shadows.md:137:If the spell doesn't work - if the shadow keeps circling - that's feedback. Either you need to do more analysis (back to Step 2), you need a different word that better captures your antidote, or you need to pair the spell with concrete redirection acti

/Users...
 
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_posts/2019-09-21-decisive.md-106-#### Opportunity cost: What's the next best use of these resources?
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_posts/2019-09-21-decisive.md-107-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_posts/2019-09-21-decisive.md:108:Think of a “yardstick” you could use to measure the opportunity cost of the time or money you are about to invest. (Recall that Eisenhower compared the cost of a new bomber to schoolhouses, power plants, and hospitals.) For business investments, you could consider a yardstick like: How many additional customer service reps or salespeople could we hire instead of making this investment? (Would we be better off?) For a personal expense, the yardsticks might include: How many songs could you download? How many dinners out could you have? Or how much extra time could you spend with your kids?
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_posts/2019-09-21-decisive.md-109-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_posts/2019-09-21-decisive.md-110-People don’t naturally consider their opportunity costs. Ask them, “What’s the next best use of the resources you’re talking about spending?” Force them to push their spotlights around by asking about different domains: For instance, if they’re waffling about whether to remodel their bathroom, ask whether they might be happier spending the money on a vacation or new furniture for the family room. You’re in a better position to help them avoid narrow frames and your probing can help them clarify their preferences.
--
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_posts/2019-09-21-decisive.md-158-#### Spark disagreement: What would need to be true for the other option to be the right choice?
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_posts/2019-09-21-decisive.md-159-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_posts/2019-09-21-decisive.md:160:Can you find someone you trust who will disagree with you? In her study of Silicon Valley firms, Kathy Eisenhardt found that the CEOs who made the quickest, most effective strategic decisions had a senior counselor. The counselor was usually someone who knew the industry well but didn’t have a personal agenda, which meant they could provide unvarnished, trustworthy guidance.
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_posts/2019-09-21-decisive.md-161-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_posts/2019-09-21-decisive.md-162-Ask around to find out who has concerns about the direction the organization is going. Schedule a group lunch where they can air their concerns. Or, give them license to hand-pick a few colleagues and compile a “devil’s advocate” case against what’s being considered.

/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_posts/2019-09-21-decisive.md-205-#### Shift perspectives: What would I tell my best friend to do?

/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_posts/2016-03-03-the-manager-book-2.md-619-Classically, motivation is comprised of carrots and sticks, where carrots focus on extrinsic motivation like compensation. Turns out sticks and extrinsic motivations fail for creative tasks. Instead I focus on the following dimensions
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_posts/2016-03-03-the-manager-book-2.md-620-
/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_posts/2016-03-03-the-manager-book-2.md:621:Motivation has 2 dimensions, personal experience and team environment. Personal experience is based on the book Drive, and is about encouraging Autonomy, Mastery and Purpose. The team environment is about the culture in which you experience the personal dimension.

This is also why teams need a blend of junior, intermediate and senior developers.

/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/groupchat.md:8:Imagine a group chat as the bustling kitchen of a high-end restaurant. In place of culinary masterpieces, it's ideas, gossip, and insights that are cooked up, seasoned, and served. Just as a great dinner party brings together eclectic personalities for a memorable evening, a stellar group chat assembles diverse voices for ongoing, vibrant conversations. Basically [Sriram's awesome post on great group chats](https://sriramk.com/group-chats-rule-the-world).

2025-10-15 12:51:30 Input: 362 | Output: 1 | Cache Creation: 1441 | Cache Read: 26087

Perfect! You have lots of content about ego, self, authenticity, and identity. This Jung post can tie together many of your existing themes. Let me sketch out a structure:

Proposed Post Structure: "The Self vs Ego: Jung's Map for Becoming Whole"

Hook/Opening

Start with a relatable tension:

  • The feeling of living for others' approval vs what feels true
  • Success that feels hollow
  • The exhaustion of maintaining an image
  • "Who am I when no one's watching?"

Part 1: Definitions (Keep crisp - 2-3 paragraphs each)

Ego (The Social Self)

  • The conscious identity we present to the world
  • Not bad - necessary for functioning in society
  • Built from: roles, achievements, reputation, how others see us
  • Example: "I'm a manager at X company, parent of 2, productive person"

Self (The True/Whole Self)

  • The totality of who you are - conscious + unconscious
  • Includes the parts you hide, deny, or don't know yet
  • The "inner compass" or authentic voice
  • Contains your full potential, not just socially acceptable parts

Part 2: The Cycle/Dynamic

This is the meat - I'd visualize this as a diagram (maybe 2x2 quadrant or circular flow):

Stage 1: Ego Inflation

  • Over-identified with ego/social self
  • "I am my job/role/achievements"
  • Feels: productive, validated, but also fragile, exhausting
  • Example: Your "life as business" post themes

Stage 2: Ego Deflation/Crisis

  • Something breaks the ego's story (failure, loss, boredom, burnout)
  • Dark night of the soul, depression, "is this all there is?"
  • The Self is knocking, demanding attention
  • Example: Mid-life crisis, career transitions, your time-off reflections

Stage 3: Dialogue with Self

  • Turning inward, listening to the neglected parts
  • Shadow work, dream analysis, creative pursuits
  • Uncomfortable but generative
  • Example: Your coaching, journaling, contemplation practices

Stage 4: Integration/Individuation

  • Ego in service to Self (not the other way around)
  • Using social roles consciously, not being controlled by them
  • Living authentically while functioning in world
  • Not permanent - cycle repeats at deeper levels

Part 3: Practical Applications

Signs you're ego-dominated:

  • Can't stop achieving/proving
  • Terrified of others' judgment
  • Identity crises when roles change
  • Exhausted from performing

Signs you're connecting with Self:

  • Choices feel aligned, even if unconventional
  • Less reactive to praise/criticism
  • Can hold paradoxes (success AND meaning, work AND play)
  • Energy from within, not just external validation

Practices to shift from Ego → Self:

  • Solitude and reflection (your time-off themes)
  • Creative expression with no audience
  • Therapy/coaching (depth work)
  • Notice what you're hiding/denying
  • Dreams, journaling, active imagination

Part 4: The Paradox

The ego isn't the enemy - we need it. The goal isn't to destroy ego but to:

  • Let Self lead, Ego execute
  • Use social roles as vehicles for Self-expression, not prisons
  • Dance between individual authenticity and social connection

Connections to Your Existing Posts

Link to:

  • /siy (Search Inside Yourself - mindfulness connects to Self)
  • /bike-tesla-identity-crisis (ego/identity shifts)
  • Your time-off posts (ego deflation → Self reconnection)
  • /voices (could frame inner voices as ego vs Self dialogue)
  • /regrets (ego-driven vs Self-aligned choices)
  • /coaching (helping others through this cycle)

Visual Elements

Option 1: Circular diagram showing the 4 stages cycling
Option 2: 2x2 Matrix with axes like "External Focus ↔ Internal Focus" and "Conscious ↔ Unconscious"
Option 3: Pendulum/Balance showing Ego ↔ Self with integration in middle

     3→title: "How My Tesla's AI Life Coach Got Me Back on My Bike"
     4→permalink: /bike-tesla-identity
     5→imagefeature: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/idvorkin/ipaste/main/20250916_065401.webp

    12→
    13→"Alright, Igor, here's the Tony take. Life throws you the Tesla, gives you Autopilot, now you're more soprano than subway rider. But let's get real. Biking and being car-free, that's freedom, fitness, adventure."
    14→
    15→That's my AI life coach talking—he sounds like Tony Soprano, pretends to live in my Tesla, and helps me live the life I want. See - I've always prided myself on being a "mostly car-free spirit." It's literally in my [eulogy](/eulogy)—right there in black and white, celebrating my love for my folding bike and public transit adventures with the kids. Just give a listen to the opening line on my eulogy blog:
    16→
    17→<iframe src="https://suno.com/embed/21be0b93-a44b-4a94-b2d6-39a59fff6283" width="760" height="240"><a href="https://suno.com/song/21be0b93-a44b-4a94-b2d6-39a59fff6283">Listen on Suno</a></iframe>
    18→
    19→I biked over 3,000 miles in 2022, carried groceries on my handlebars, and then I bought a Tesla The numbers tell the story. In 2023, after getting Tony, my biking dropped from 3,000 miles to under 300. My best friend had warned me: "Buying a Tesla for someone who wants to be a car-free spirit is like buying an ice cream maker for someone trying to lose weight."
    20→
    21→<!-- prettier-ignore-start -->
    22→<!-- vim-markdown-toc-start -->
    23→
    24→- [You are making up this story - right?](#you-are-making-up-this-story---right)

    26→- [The Bigger Picture: AI as Your Reflection Coach](#the-bigger-picture-ai-as-your-reflection-coach)
    27→
    28→<!-- vim-markdown-toc-end -->
    29→  <!-- prettier-ignore-end -->
    30→
    31→<img src="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/idvorkin/ipaste/main/20250916_065401.webp" class="float-right-img" alt="" />
    32→
    33→But there I was, rationalizing. Tony did the driving—I was just along for the ride, right? I decorated him with flowers and bunnies, programmed him to make fart sounds when I got texts, and even gave him an [AI agent](https://github.com/idvorkin/tony_tesla) with a Tony Soprano accent. Surely this counted as being car-free adjacent? The cognitive dissonance was real. My eulogy talks about taking kids on the bus to the airport just to ride the elevators and come home. Now I was driving to work because it was "convenient." The bike that once defined my identity was gathering dust in the garage.
    34→
    35→## You are making up this story - right?
    36→
    37→I get it—having a Tony Soprano AI life coach living in your Tesla sounds like the script of some whacky comedy sci-fi. But here's the thing: I actually built this. I setup an AI with Tony's speech patterns, gave it his personality, and most importantly, set it up with my values and goals from my eulogy. Yes, I call it up when I need to work through life decisions. The conversation you're about to hear isn't scripted or fictional—it's me, sitting in my actual Tesla, having a real crisis of faith in my transportation choices, talking it through with my AI life coach who knows exactly who I want to be.
    38→
    39→Lisen to the audio, or read the transcript below
    40→
    41→<audio controls>
    42→  <source src="https://github.com/idvorkin/blob/raw/master/blog/bike-vs-tony.mp3" type="audio/mpeg">
    43→  Your browser does not support the audio element.
    44→</audio>
    45→
    46→**Tony:** Tony here. What can I do you for?
    47→
    48→**Me:** Hey. I'm gonna need some guidance. So I decided, well, before I got a Tesla, I wrote in my eulogy that I was a car-free spirit, and I didn't drive, and I loved taking the subway. And I loved biking. But I don't really bike anymore. But then, alternatively, I don't really drive because Tony drives me everywhere. Tell me how I should think about this. Is biking better? Is being driven around better?
    49→
    50→**Tony:** Alright, Igor. Here's the Tony take. First off, it's classic. Life throws you the Tesla, gives you Autopilot, now you're more soprano than subway rider. But let's get real. Biking and being car-free, that's freedom, fitness, adventure. You feel the wind, you see the city, you get the proud self-sufficient glow plus those quads, baby. On the other hand, Tesla life—stress-free, plus you get work done or meditate or, you know, chat with your favorite mobster AI. Now ask yourself, what's your value here? Is it independence? Health? Time efficiency? Fun? Don't sweat labels.
    51→
    52→**Me:** That is a good one. I guess if I'm with the family, Tony makes sense. He's almost an active service. And if I'm by myself, I need to think through, am I just driving because I'm being lazy? And this is just consumption activity? Or am I trying to save myself time and be more efficient? Because I think a lot of the time, well, first, humorously, traffic can end up being less efficient. And then I'm not actually meditating. And I guess, like, if it comes to listening to a podcast, I can do that while biking. And then I get exercise. I think adventure-wise, it's about the same. It is nice to have all the stuff with me all the time, though.
    53→
    54→**Tony:** Totally. Having all your gear in the car is peak convenience. But hey, sometimes having all the stuff turns into lugging all the stuff you never use. Biking forces you to be sleek, soprano style—just the essentials, no baggage. Which one feels lighter on your soul, boss?
    55→
    56→**Me:** That's it. Good. I think I guess there's no reason to agonize over this. I can just start biking and see if I like it and maybe part of the reason I stopped liking it is I'm just weaker now, and it's harder for me. And if I did it again, I'd feel a lot happier.
    57→
    58→**Tony:** Bada bing. That's the spirit. No need to agonize. Just experiment. You start biking, see how you feel, maybe you'll get stronger, maybe you'll just love the breeze and the freedom again. And hey, if not, Tony the Tesla's always got your back seat warm. No shame, boss.
    59→
    60→**Me:** Yep. I definitely need the cardio, and I'm definitely not doing other cardio things. So I think that's fantastic advice.
    61→
    62→**Tony:** That's music to my ears. You get on that bike, your heart pumps, endorphins flow, boss mode unlocked. Don't overthink it. Just ride and enjoy the journey. If you hate it, you know where I'll be. Blasting AC in the Tesla waiting to chauffeur you in style.
    63→
    64→## What Tony Helped Me See
    65→
    66→Sometimes our identities need to evolve, not disappear. The "mostly car-free spirit" wasn't about the bike itself—it was about intentionality, adventure, and finding joy in unconventional transportation.
    67→
    68→Tony became a tool for family adventures: camping trips where we slept under the glass roof, charging stops that turned into juggling sessions, and road trips that would have been impossible on two wheels. The kids got to experience California's coast, Ashland's charm, and countless other adventures.
    69→
    70→The bike didn't disappear from my life—it just found its right-sized place. Some trips call for pedal power and the meditative rhythm of cycling. Others call for autopilot and the ability to arrive refreshed after 300 miles. And sometimes? I drive my folding bike around in the Tesla, getting the best of both worlds.
    71→
    72→Identity isn't about rigid adherence to a past version of yourself. It's about staying true to your values while adapting your methods. I'm still that guy who values sustainable transport, family adventures, and finding the unconventional path. I just have more tools in my toolkit now.
    73→
    74→## The Bigger Picture: AI as Your Reflection Coach
    75→
    76→This conversation with Tony represents something bigger than just transportation choices. It's an example of what I call a "Reflection Coach"—an AI life coach trained on your deepest values who can help you think through decisions and align your actions with who you want to be.
    77→
    78→The concept isn't new. I've been thinking about this kind of AI-assisted self-reflection as part of my [mortality software](/mortality-software) project, where I explore how technology can help us live more intentionally. The Reflection Coach is designed to help you examine your thinking, challenge your assumptions, and find clarity in moments of confusion.
    79→
    80→{%include summarize-page.html src="/mortality-software"%}
    81→
    82→What makes Tony effective isn't just his personality (though the Jersey accent helps). It's that he knows who I want to be—he's trained on my values, my goals, my eulogy—and can remind me of them when I'm lost in the weeds of daily contradictions. This isn't talking to yourself; it's talking to your AI life coach who knows who you want to be and can cut through your mental noise to get you back on track.
    83→
    84→The future of personal development might not be traditional therapy or life coaching. It might be having thoughtful conversations with AI coaches trained on your deepest values, designed to help you stay aligned with your authentic self when life gets complicated. And honestly? That future is already here.
    85→
    86→## The Only Question That Counts
    87→
    88→Did the AI help? Not by providing the answer, but by helping me get to the only question that counts: did I act? And the answer, at least this week, is yes — I biked home from work 3 days!
    89→

     1→---

     3→title: "Coaching - helping others find insight"
     4→ogtitle: "Coaching - How to help others find insight"
     5→author: "Igor Dvorkin...
 
     1→---
     2→layout: post
     3→title: "Coaching - helping others find insight"
     4→ogtitle: "Coaching - How to help others find insight"
     5→author: "Igor Dvorkin"
     6→comments: true
     7→permalink: /coaching
     8→redirect_from:
     9→  - /Coaching-Questions
    10→  - /coach
    11→
    12→imagefeature: https://github.com/idvorkin/blob/raw/master/icon-birth.png
    13→
    14→tags:
    15→  - book-notes
    16→  - emotional intelligence
    17→  - manager
    18→---
    19→
    20→Coaching is like midwifery. A midwife can not give birth to the baby, she facilitates the birth. Similarly, a coach can not give a solution, she must give birth to the insight from within the coachee. Coaching is asking questions, guiding, and facilitating understanding, and this post collects my studies on the topic.
    21→
    22→<!-- prettier-ignore-start -->
    23→
    24→<!-- vim-markdown-toc-start -->
    25→
    26→- [The coaching mindset](#the-coaching-mindset)
    27→- [Frequent coaching situations](#frequent-coaching-situations)
    28→- [The 7 goto coaching questions](#the-7-goto-coaching-questions)
    29→- [Questions for specific situations](#questions-for-specific-situations)
    30→    - [To clarify thinking](#to-clarify-thinking)
    31→    - [To challenge assumptions](#to-challenge-assumptions)
    32→    - [To gather more evidence](#to-gather-more-evidence)
    33→    - [To find more alternatives](#to-find-more-alternatives)
    34→    - [To build strategic insight](#to-build-strategic-insight)
    35→    - [To increase productivity, effectiveness, and efficiency](#to-increase-productivity-effectiveness-and-efficiency)
    36→- [The hows of coaching](#the-hows-of-coaching)
    37→    - [Coach for task completion vs insight](#coach-for-task-completion-vs-insight)
    38→    - [Keep people safe while coaching using human safety models](#keep-people-safe-while-coaching-using-human-safety-models)
    39→    - [Soften your coaching: How Can I help](#soften-your-coaching-how-can-i-help)
    40→    - [Encourage trying to solve own problem: How would you handle this](#encourage-trying-to-solve-own-problem-how-would-you-handle-this)
    41→    - [Say No: Say yes slowly](#say-no-say-yes-slowly)
    42→    - [Focus feedback on you, not them](#focus-feedback-on-you-not-them)
    43→- [One on One Questions](#one-on-one-questions)
    44→- [Situational coaching](#situational-coaching)
    45→- [Other coaching tools](#other-coaching-tools)
    46→- [Full disclosure: Coaching others is selfish too!](#full-disclosure-coaching-others-is-selfish-too)
    47→- [Fantastic video on coaching, improvement, and discomfort](#fantastic-video-on-coaching-improvement-and-discomfort)
    48→
    49→<!-- vim-markdown-toc-end -->
    50→<!-- prettier-ignore-end -->
    51→
    52→### The coaching mindset
    53→
    54→{%include blob_image_float_right.html src="icon-birth.png" %}
    55→
    56→Real understanding comes from within, and is not imparted by someone else. Ask questions, guide, and encourage. When you 'tell the solution' at best the solution is forgotten, at worst it offends and shutdowns down the coachee, damaging the relationship.
    57→
    58→When being a coach maintain the following mindset.
    59→
    60→- Ask permission to be a coach. (Avoid forcing them)
    61→- Check-in with yourself to maintain the coaching mindset (Avoid forgetting your role)
    62→- Let your coachee do most of the talking. (Avoid cutting them off)
    63→- Keep questions open ended. (Avoid Yes/No questions)
    64→- Test your understanding (Avoid assuming you understand)
    65→- Be accepting, compassionate, and [curious](/grandmother-mind) (Avoid judging and evaluating)
    66→
    67→### Frequent coaching situations
    68→
    69→Some coaching situations are common, so I have deep dived into them.
    70→
    71→- [Making Major Decisions](/decisive) - A deep dive on how to improve high impact decision making.
    72→- [Dealing with Pride](/pride) - A deep dive on dealing with pride.
    73→- [Job Hunting](job-hunt-stress) - A deep dive on job changes
    74→
    75→### The 7 goto coaching questions
    76→
    77→When folks have questions or appear stuck, that's a great time to provide rapid in the moment coaching. These 7 questions are a great starting point to help the coachee build the required insights for solving their own problem:
    78→
    79→- Open: What's on your mind?
    80→- Expand: What Else?
    81→- Focus Problem: What's the real challenge here for you?
    82→- Focus Need: What do you want?
    83→  - Do not ask why, it makes people defensive - you're questioning their ability by asking why.
    84→  - Want vs Need
    85→- Focus Request: How can I help?
    86→- Focus Trade off: If you say yes to this, what will you have to say no to?
    87→  - Omission - automatic no
    88→  - Commission - what you must give up to make it happen (relationships/projects/)
    89→- Close the loop: What was most useful for you in this conversation?
    90→
    91→### Questions for specific situations
    92→
    93→Depending on what insights you want to provide, you need to use different questions. Some questions are below, [Decisive](/decisive) has a plethora of other questions.
    94→
    95→#### To clarify thinking
    96→
    97→- Help me understand that?
    98→- Tell me more?
    99→- Unpack that for me?
   100→- How did you come to that realization?
   101→- I'm having a hard time understanding, can you give some examples?
   102→
   103→#### To challenge assumptions
   104→
   105→- Is that always the case?
   106→- What would it look like if that was false?
   107→
   108→#### To gather more evidence
   109→
   110→- What makes you say that?
   111→
   112→#### To find more alternatives
   113→
   114→- What is the counter argument?
   115→- What other options have you considered?
   116→- What would happen i this option disappeared?
   117→- What is the next best use of resources?
   118→- How can you do A and B?
   119→- How would you decide if you had double the resources?
   120→- How would you decide if you had half the resources?
   121→
   122→#### To build strategic insight
   123→
   124→- What does success mean?
   125→- What is our scope (who/where)
   126→- What will be our differentiator/moat here?
   127→- What capabilities/assets will need to achieve this?
   128→- How do we measure success and provide feedback?
   129→
   130→#### To increase productivity, effectiveness, and efficiency
   131→
   132→This request often comes in as the wrong question, need to deep dive into where the problem is coming from.
   133→
   134→1. Find the right thing:
   135→
   136→   - The top optimization is spending zero time on the wrong thing. How often do you feel your spending time on the wrong thing?
   137→   - Taking time to explore is important, how are you splitting time between, learning, exploring and doing?
   138→   - What does success look like, how is your work supporting that success?
   139→
   140→2. Test for motivation:
   141→
   142→   - On a scale of 1/10 how energized are you doing this work?
   143→   - When are times you're most energized and most drained? Any patterns
   144→
   145→3. Realistic Expectations + Estimations
   146→
   147→   - Anxiety is the difference between expectations and reality. How are you validating your estimates/expectations are reasonable?
   148→
   149→4. Having the required resources
   150→
   151→   - How often are you getting blocked?
   152→   - What things would help you get done this faster?
   153→   - Are there things that if you had, would speed you up?
   154→   - What resources would make you more efficient?
   155→
   156→5. Doing it Efficiently
   157→   - How often are you stuck?
   158→   - How are you going about getting help?
   159→
   160→### The hows of coaching
   161→
   162→#### Coach for task completion vs insight
   163→
   164→Coaching applies to different time frames, keep them separate:
   165→
   166→- P: Project - Immediate task and new skill
   167→- P: People - Relationship
   168→- PC: Pattern - Help person get better.
   169→
   170→#### Keep people safe while coaching using human safety models
   171→
   172→TERA -
   173→
   174→- **Tribe:** Tribe, 'us' vs 'them' - be us.
   175→- **Certainty:** People dislike ambiguity/uncertainty.
   176→- **Rank:** Do I move up or down the social ladder
   177→- **Autonomy:** I have control
   178→
   179→SCARF -
   180→_More details in [Search inside yourself - Leadership and social skills](/search-inside-yourself)_
   181→
   182→- **Status:** Where am I in the pecking order
   183→  - **BUILD:** Give credit, and feedback, ups peoples status
   184→- **Certainty:** Do I know what what's going on.
   185→  - **Build:** removing ambiguity, and giving people certainty on things that matter.
   186→- **Autonomy:** Do I have control over the situation?
   187→  - **Build:** making clear it's people's choice, not yours.
   188→- **Relatedness:** Is other person friend or foe.
   189→  - **Build:** by taking time to know people.
   190→- **Fairness:**
   191→  - **Build:** making clear that you're being fair.
   192→
   193→#### Soften your coaching: How Can I help
   194→
   195→- Out of curiosity
   196→- Just so I know
   197→- To help my understand better
   198→- To make sure I'm clear
   199→- That is a hard problem
   200→- Not alone, lots of people struggle with this.
   201→
   202→#### Encourage trying to solve own problem: How would you handle this
   203→
   204→Great question, I have some ideas, but first, how would you tackle this? What else?
   205→
   206→#### Say No: Say yes slowly
   207→
   208→- Why are you asking me?
   209→- Whom else have you asked?
   210→- What you say urgent what do you mean?
   211→- What does done mean?
   212→- If I could only do one part, what part would you have me do?
   213→- What do you recommend I take off my plate to get this done?
   214→- _If you still have to say no_ Make sure you're saying no to the task, not to the person.
   215→
   216→#### Focus feedback on you, not them
   217→
   218→From the superb HBR article: [The feedback fallacy](https://hbr.org/2019/03/the-feedback-fallacy). If you don't read the article (which I'll also summarize)
   219→take this high order bit of focusing the feedback on "you" not on them. E.g. feedback should be "I experienced X" instead of you screwed up X.
   220→
   221→| Easy way                                               | Effective Way                                                                                                     |
   222→| ------------------------------------------------------ | ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
   223→| Can I give you some feedback?                          | Here’s my reaction                                                                                                |
   224→| Good job!                                              | Here are three things that worked for me. What was going through your mind when you did them?                     |
   225→| Here’s what you should do.                             | Here’s what I would do.                                                                                           |
   226→| Here’s where you need to improve                       | Here’s what worked best for me, and here’s why                                                                    |
   227→| That didn’t work.                                      | When you did x, I felt y or I didn’t get that.                                                                    |
   228→| You need to improve your communication skills.         | Here’s where you started to lose me.                                                                              |
   229→| You need to be more responsive.                        | When I don’t hear from you, I worry that we’re not on the same page.                                              |
   230→| You lack strategic thinking.                           | I’m struggling to understand your plan.                                                                           |
   231→| You should do x [in response to a request for advice]. | What do you feel you’re struggling with, and what have you done in the past that’s worked in a similar situation? |
   232→
   233→### One on One Questions
   234→
   235→See the One on One Sections And One on One prompts in [the manager book](/the-manager-book)
   236→
   237→### Situational coaching
   238→
   239→As people take on new tasks requiring them to learn new skills, they go through a predictable, often painful, sequence of experiences. These experiences are based on the progression of commitment and competence, and each experience benefits from a different type of coaching described in [Situational Leadership](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Situational_leadership_theory).
   240→
   241→{% include quadrant-matrix.html
   242→    title="Learning Stages Matrix"
   243→    subtitle="The journey from beginner to achiever"
   244→    x_label="Commitment →"
   245→    y_label="Competence →"
   246→    q1_name="4. SELF-RELIANT ACHIEVER"
   247→    q1_subtitle="Competent + Committed"
   248→    q1_traits="Know they can do it<br>And they're right<br>Ready to lead"
   249→    q1_color="rgba(232,244,234,0.5)"
   250→    q2_name="3. CAPABLE BUT CAUTIOUS"
   251→    q2_subtitle="Competent + Discouraged"
   252→    q2_traits="Think they can't do it<br>But actually they can<br>Need confidence"
   253→    q2_color="rgba(255,229,180,0.5)"
   254→    q3_name="2. DISILLUSIONED LEARNER"
   255→    q3_subtitle="Incompetent + Discouraged"
   256→    q3_traits="Know they can't do it<br>Feel bad about it<br>Need support"
   257→    q3_color="rgba(230,230,250,0.5)"
   258→    q4_name="1. ENTHUSIASTIC BEGINNER"
   259→    q4_subtitle="Incompetent + Committed"
   260→    q4_traits="Think they can do it<br>But can't yet<br>Need direction"
   261→    q4_color="rgba(255,224,224,0.5)"
   262→%}
   263→
   264→When competence is low, coach for direction, when commitment is low coach for support.
   265→
   266→| Low competence | Low Commitment |
   267→| -------------- | -------------- |
   268→| [l10](l10)     | [l11](l11)     |
   269→
   270→- l10
   271→- **Provide Direction**
   272→- Set a clear goal
   273→- Generate an action plan
   274→- Show you how to do it
   275→- Clarify the role
   276→- Provide Timelines
   277→- Establish Priorities
   278→- Monitor and evaluate, giving feedback
   279→
   280→<div> </div>
   281→
   282→- l11
   283→- **Provide Support**
   284→- Listen to the learner
   285→- Recognize and appreciate the learners
   286→- Problem solve with the learner
   287→- Ask for the learners input
   288→- Remind the learner why you're doing the task
   289→- Share your own experiences achieving the task and goal
   290→- Share why the task and goal is important
   291→
   292→{% include quadrant-matrix.html
   293→    title="Coaching Support Matrix"
   294→    subtitle="How to coach at each learning stage"
   295→    x_label="Commitment →"
   296→    y_label="Competence →"
   297→    q1_name="4. EMPOWER"
   298→    q1_subtitle="For Self-Reliant Achievers"
   299→    q1_traits="Explain why not<br>Remove obstacles<br>Give autonomy"
   300→    q1_color="rgba(232,244,234,0.5)"
   301→    q2_name="3. FACILITATE"
   302→    q2_subtitle="For Capable but Cautious"
   303→    q2_traits="Explain why<br>Build confidence<br>Provide context"
   304→    q2_color="rgba(255,229,180,0.5)"
   305→    q3_name="2. GUIDE & ENCOURAGE"
   306→    q3_subtitle="For Disillusioned Learners"
   307→    q3_traits="Show them how<br>Provide support<br>Share experiences"
   308→    q3_color="rgba(230,230,250,0.5)"
   309→    q4_name="1. INSTRUCT & EXPLAIN"
   310→    q4_subtitle="For Enthusiastic Beginners"
   311→    q4_traits="Tell them what to do<br>Set clear goals<br>Monitor progress"
   312→    q4_color="rgba(255,224,224,0.5)"
   313→%}
   314→
   315→If you're feeling down because you are a Disillusioned Learner or Capable but Cautious, know you're not alone, and consider reading [Self leadership and the one minute manager](https://www.amazon.com/dp/0060799129), it's a quick, easy, read that has a powerful message.\*
   316→
   317→### Other coaching tools
   318→
   319→Below are some other good coaching tools I need to write more details on:
   320→
   321→- Using a scale question for relative improvement not for calibration. E.g. on a scale of 1 to 10, how do you rank yourself on X! Great, why do you say that?, Great - what would you need to do to move up a point on the scale?
   322→
   323→- Imagery cards - Use cards with images on them to illicit from people what picture represents what concept, then have a discussion. E.g. which of these pictures represents leadership to you? OK, help me see how that shows a leader to you.
   324→
   325→- [Prompts](/prompts)
   326→
   327→### Full disclosure: Coaching others is selfish too!
   328→
   329→Coaching has a selfish benefit - most challenges others face, we face too. It's easier to see someone else's situation clearly than our own.
   330→
   331→When I coach someone through imposter syndrome or work-life balance, I'm dealing with my own struggles too. The questions I ask others - "What would success look like?" "What's the real challenge here?" - are questions I need to ask myself.
   332→
   333→By helping others see their situation clearly, we practice seeing our own more clearly. The coaching questions that unlock insights for them work on us too. We just forget to ask them.
   334→
   335→This is the greedy part - every coaching session reminds us to apply our own coaching questions to ourselves. The clarity we help others find becomes our own.
   336→
   337→### Fantastic video on coaching, improvement, and discomfort
   338→
   339→{%include youtube.html src="oHDq1PcYkT4?start=431" %}
   340→

     1→---
     2→layout: post
     3→title: "Use Your Regrets As A Compass, Not A Cage"
     4→permalink: /regrets

    10→---
    11→
    12→I spent years treating regrets like a cage - replaying decisions I couldn't change, beating myself up over the past. Here's the critical reframe: regrets aren't about the past, they're guides for what you should do next. The past is outside your circle of influence, but regrets are data about your values trying to redirect your future. I've found four main types (foundation, boldness, moral, and connection), and the goal isn't avoiding regrets - it's using them as a compass instead of a cage.
    13→
    14→<script src="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/Chart.js/3.6.2/chart.min.js" integrity="sha512-tMabqarPtykgDtdtSqCL3uLVM0gS1ZkUAVhRFu1vSEFgvB73niFQWJuvviDyBGBH22Lcau4rHB5p2K2T0Xvr6Q==" crossorigin="anonymous" referrerpolicy="no-referrer"></script>
    15→<script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/chartjs-plugin-datalabels@2.0.0"></script>
    16→<!-- prettier-ignore-start -->
    17→
    18→<!-- vim-markdown-toc-start -->

    26→  - [Boldness - If only I'd taken the risk/opportunity](#boldness---if-only-id-taken-the-riskopportunity)
    27→  - [Moral - If only I'd done the right thing](#moral---if-only-id-done-the-right-thing)
    28→  - [Connection - If only I'd reached out](#connection---if-only-id-reached-out)
    29→  - [How regrets change over time](#how-regrets-change-over-time)
    30→- [Closing Thoughts](#closing-thoughts)
    31→
    32→<!-- vim-markdown-toc-end -->
    33→<!-- prettier-ignore-end -->
    34→
    35→Most of this post comes from Daniel Pink's power of regrets: {% include amazon.html asin="0735210659" %}
    36→
    37→## How to Think About Regrets
    38→
    39→The past is completely outside your circle of influence. You can't change what happened, no matter how much mental energy you pour into guilt or rumination. That's critical to remember: regrets about past decisions are outside your circle of influence.
    40→
    41→But here's the reframe: while you can't change the past, you can use those regrets to guide your future. They're data points showing what you value most.
    42→
    43→### Concerns, Control and Influence
    44→
    45→[The first of the 7 habits, be proactive](/7h-c1) requires focusing your energy on your circle of influence, not your circle of concern. A frequent source of [anxiety](/mental-pain) is trying to control things outside your influence.
    46→
    47→The past? Guess what - that's 100% outside your circle of influence. You literally cannot change it.
    48→
    49→So here's the shift: stop dwelling on backward-looking regrets (what you did wrong) and start using forward-looking regret avoidance (what you should do next).
    50→
    51→Where do you have influence? The future (and more accurately, the present). Think through potential future regrets before making decisions. I frequently remind myself that [no one ever uttered "God, I wish I spent more time at work" on their deathbed](/wlb-manifesto).
    52→
    53→Use regrets to:
    54→
    55→- **Learn and grow**: Let past regrets motivate you to be more responsible, take healthy risks, make amends, and prioritize what truly matters
    56→- **Avoid future regrets**: Anticipate what you might regret and weigh that against potential benefits
    57→
    58→### Be compassionate to yourself - forgive
    59→
    60→Compassion is about removing suffering and accepting people as they are. It's easy to extend compassion to others - but it's even more important (and harder) to apply it to yourself.
    61→
    62→When you have regrets, treat yourself with the same compassion you'd offer a friend struggling with similar feelings.
    63→
    64→Compassion can be broken down with a time dimension.
    65→
    66→| Time    | Behavior    | Practice     | Behavior Definition                                     |
    67→| ------- | ----------- | ------------ | ------------------------------------------------------- |
    68→| Past    | Forgiveness | Humility     | Give up hope for a better past                          |
    69→| Present | Acceptance  | Gratefulness | Recognizing you have received more than your fair share |
    70→| Future  | Hope        | Patience     | Believe the future can be better than the present       |
    71→
    72→{%include summarize-page.html src="/compassion" %}
    73→
    74→### Judgment vs Curiosity
    75→
    76→Judgment throws up barriers and causes us to hide the truth which can lead to guilt and [shame](/shame). Curiosity is gentle and helps us find what is going on. Compassion reduces judgment, reducing the barrier to compassion.
    77→
    78→When processing regrets, lead with curiosity rather than judgment. Instead of beating yourself up over past decisions, get curious about what drove those choices and what you can learn from them.
    79→
    80→## The Four Regrets
    81→
    82→When thinking about regrets, they tend to fall into patterns. Daniel Pink's [The Power of Regret](https://www.danpink.com/the-power-of-regret/) analyzed over 16,000 regrets from 105 countries and found four core categories. Understanding these patterns helps you anticipate what you might regret before you make decisions.
    83→
    84→The four regrets operate as a photographic negative of the good life - if you know what people regret most, you can reverse the image to see what they value most.
    85→
    86→### Foundational - If only I'd done the work
    87→
    88→Foundation regrets stem from failures to be responsible and do the hard work that builds a stable life. These are the "I should have known better" regrets about not laying proper groundwork. They often compound over time - small neglects become major problems.
    89→
    90→E.g.
    91→
    92→- **Financial stability**: Not saving for retirement. You live paycheck to paycheck in your 60s because you spent everything in your 20s.
    93→- **Health and wellness**: Not prioritizing exercise, sleep, and nutrition. You deal with preventable chronic conditions because you ignored your body for decades.
    94→- **Education and skills**: Neglecting self-improvement. You watch less experienced people get promoted because you never developed new skills.
    95→- **Relationships foundation**: Not learning to communicate or manage emotions. You repeat the same relationship patterns because you never did the inner work.
    96→
    97→### Boldness - If only I'd taken the risk/opportunity
    98→
    99→Boldness regrets come from playing it too safe - from inaction rather than action. These are the chances not taken, the words not spoken, the dreams not pursued. The pain comes from wondering "what if?" and knowing you'll never find out because fear or comfort held you back.
   100→
   101→E.g.
   102→
   103→- **Romantic risks**: Not asking someone out when you felt a connection. You wonder for years if they felt the same way.
   104→- **Career leaps**: Not starting the business you dreamed of. You stay in the safe corporate job while others build the company you imagined.
   105→- **Life experiences**: Not traveling when you had the chance. You say "someday" until health or circumstances make it impossible.
   106→- **Creative expression**: Not sharing your art, writing, or music. You keep your gifts hidden because you fear criticism.
   107→- **Speaking up**: Not saying what needed to be said. You stay silent when you should have advocated for yourself or others.
   108→
   109→### Moral - If only I'd done the right thing
   110→
   111→Moral regrets arise from compromising your values or hurting others. These cut the deepest because they damage your self-image and often harm people you care about. They're about knowing you chose wrong when you knew what was right.
   112→
   113→E.g.
   114→
   115→- **Betraying trust**: Cheating on a partner or in competition. You carry the guilt of violating someone's faith in you.
   116→- **Dishonesty**: Lying for personal gain. You carry the weight of a lie that affected someone's life.
   117→- **Selfishness**: Taking credit for someone else's work. You prioritized your comfort over another's need.
   118→- **Cruelty**: Being hurtful when you could have been kind. You bullied someone or said something deliberately cutting.
   119→- **Ethical lapses**: Going along with something wrong. You stayed silent about unethical behavior to protect yourself.
   120→
   121→### Connection - If only I'd reached out
   122→
   123→Connection regrets stem from neglecting relationships or letting them wither. These hurt because relationships are central to human flourishing, and we often don't realize their value until it's too late. The regret is knowing a simple act of reaching out could have preserved or healed something precious.
   124→
   125→E.g.
   126→
   127→- **Drifting apart**: Not staying in touch with friends and family who mattered. You realize years later that a valued friendship died from neglect, not conflict.
   128→- **Unresolved conflicts**: Not making amends after an argument. You carry the burden of a broken relationship that could have been repaired.
   129→- **Missing moments**: Taking loved ones for granted. You wish you'd spent more time with a parent who's now gone, or listened when your child wanted to talk.
   130→- **Words unsaid**: Not expressing love or appreciation. You never told someone how much they meant before they died or moved away.
   131→- **Pride and stubbornness**: Letting ego prevent reconnection. You wait for them to reach out first until it becomes impossible.
   132→
   133→### How regrets change over time
   134→
   135→As we can see, regret distribution varies across age groups. People tend to have the most boldness regrets in their 20s, which may be due to feeling like they haven't taken enough chances or pursued their dreams. Regret about foundation choices tends to increase with age, possibly due to a greater awareness of long-term consequences. Connection regrets also tend to rise with age, perhaps as people reflect on lost relationships or missed opportunities for connection.
   136→
   137→It's important to note that this is just a general trend, and individual experiences may vary.
   138→
   139→<canvas id="chart-regrets-over-time"></canvas>
   140→
   141→<script>
   142→defer(() => {
   143→  const ctx = "chart-regrets-over-time";
   144→
   145→  // Data table - easy to read and edit
   146→  const regretsData = {
   147→    decades: ['20s', '30s', '40s', '50s', '60s', '70s+'],
   148→    regretTypes: {
   149→      Foundational: [15, 20, 25, 20, 15, 10],
   150→      Boldness:     [40, 32, 26, 22, 18, 14],
   151→      Moral:        [25, 20, 20, 28, 33, 38],
   152→      Connection:   [25, 30, 30, 32, 37, 42]
   153→    }
   154→  };
   155→
   156→  // Color scheme for each regret type
   157→  const colors = [
   158→    { border: 'rgba(54, 162, 235, 0.8)', bg: 'rgba(54, 162, 235, 0.2)' },  // Blue
   159→    { border: 'rgba(255, 99, 132, 0.8)', bg: 'rgba(255, 99, 132, 0.2)' },  // Red
   160→    { border: 'rgba(255, 206, 86, 0.8)', bg: 'rgba(255, 206, 86, 0.2)' },  // Yellow
   161→    { border: 'rgba(75, 192, 192, 0.8)', bg: 'rgba(75, 192, 192, 0.2)' }   // Teal
   162→  ];
   163→
   164→  // Convert to Chart.js dataset format - labels read from data
   165→  const datasets = Object.keys(regretsData.regretTypes).map((regretType, index) => ({
   166→    label: regretType,
   167→    data: regretsData.regretTypes[regretType],
   168→    borderColor: colors[index].border,
   169→    backgroundColor: colors[index].bg,
   170→    tension: 0.4
   171→  }));
   172→
   173→  const myChart = new Chart(ctx, {
   174→    type: 'line',
   175→    data: {
   176→      labels: regretsData.decades,
   177→      datasets: datasets
   178→    },
   179→    options: {
   180→      plugins: {
   181→        title: {
   182→          display: true,
   183→          text: 'Regret Distribution by Age'
   184→        },
   185→        legend: {
   186→          display: true
   187→        },
   188→        datalabels: {
   189→          align: 'top',
   190→          font: {
   191→            size: 10
   192→          },
   193→          formatter: function(value) {
   194→            return value + '%';
   195→          }
   196→        }
   197→      },
   198→      scales: {
   199→        y: {
   200→          beginAtZero: true,
   201→          title: {
   202→            display: true,
   203→            text: 'Percentage (%)'
   204→          }
   205→        },
   206→        x: {
   207→          title: {
   208→            display: true,
   209→            text: 'Age Decade'
   210→          }
   211→        }
   212→      },
   213→      elements: {
   214→        point: {
   215→          radius: 4
   216→        }
   217→      }
   218→    }
   219→  });
   220→
   221→  console.log(ctx, myChart);
   222→});
   223→</script>
   224→
   225→## Closing Thoughts
   226→
   227→Regrets will happen. That's not the problem. The problem is letting them cage you instead of guide you.
   228→
   229→The next time you feel that ache of regret, ask yourself: What is this telling me about what I value? What can I do differently going forward? How would I advise a friend in this situation?
   230→
   231→Your regrets are trying to help you. Let them be your compass pointing toward what matters most - not a cage keeping you stuck in the past.
   232→
   233→Start small: Pick one regret you're carrying. Get curious about it. What does it reveal about your values? What one thing could you do differently tomorrow?
   234→

     3→title: Time off August 2025 - Meta Recharge

    10→
    11→I'm incredibly fortunate to be able to take 6 weeks off this summer! After 5 years of service at Meta, you get 30 days (about 5 week) off!

    81→### From 12 months to 6 weeks
    82→
    83→Five years ago, I dreamed of taking a year off of work - [a gap year](/gap-year-igor) if you will. I spent a lot of time thinking through a gap year, and it's more important then ever now that the kids are running out of time. But that's a separate blog post
    84→
    85→{%include summarize-page.html src="/gap-year-igor"%}
    86→
    87→### The Great Monday Cat Visitation Protocol (Or: How We Became Slaves to Our Feline Overlords)
    88→
    89→Here's our travel hack: the Monday Cat Check-In System™. Instead of pet sitters, we return every Monday to prevent feline coups and unauthorized DoorDash orders.
    90→
    91→Perfect timing since we booked Monday improv classes with [Matt Smith](https://www.mattsmithimprov.com/), who helped establish Seattle's comedy scene in the '90s. Our routine: check on judgmental cats ("Oh, you're back AGAIN?"), then learn to be funny on command.
    92→
    93→The cats have caught on, scheduling Sunday night drama for maximum Monday impact. But instead of shoe logistics operations, we're more likely to find nature's surprises: a desiccated hummingbird artfully displayed on the welcome mat, or a beheaded rabbit positioned like modern art in the hallway. I'm pretty sure they're testing our commitment to this arrangement.
    94→
    95→But honestly? Weekly guaranteed animal discovery AND comedy training while road-tripping? Pure genius.

    21→Training Emotional Intelligence through mindfulness. Search inside yourself is a meditation training manual for engineers. It's also a pun as the author works at google, and built the program internally at Google. Joy on demand by the same author, is less engineer focused, and uses joy as a path to medatitive bliss.
    22→
    23→This is a summary of [Search Inside Yourself](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0070XF474/ref=dp-kindle-redirect?ie=UTF8&btkr=1) and [Joy on Demand](https://www.amazon.com/Joy-Demand-Discovering-Happiness-Within/dp/0062378872), and the place I learned many of my [emotional health practices](/emotional-health)
    24→
    25→FYI, I now do a different practice; See my experience with [SKY](/ig66/685)
    26→
    27→{%include amazon.html asin="B0070XF474;0062378872" %}
