    48→
    49→### 1) What is Emotional Intelligence (EI)? How to train it?
    50→
    51→{%include local_image_float_right.html src="raccoon-meditate.png" %}
    52→
    53→_Even engineers can use empathy_
    54→
    55→- **GOAL:EI is a collection of trainable skills, this book teaches them.**
    56→- IE is Ability to monitor your, and others, feelings, and use the info to guide your own thinking and actions.
    57→- Background on EI: [What makes a leader](/what-makes-a-leader) article.
    58→- Foundational Skill 1: Focus attention
    59→- Foundational Skill 2: Perceive feelings in the body since body manifests feelings
    60→  1. before mind realizes it
    61→  2. with more granularity.
    62→- Mindfulness is THE WAY to build those foundational skills.
    63→- Once have the mindfulness can use to build the components of EI.
    64→- Easy and Easier Mindfulness Methods. **Easy** follow the breath. **Easier** have no thoughts.
    65→- For a complementary personality framework, see [PANAS Personality Types](/emotions#panas-personality-types) - knowing if you're a Mad Scientist, Cheerleader, Judge, or Poet can inform your EI practice.
    66→
    67→### 2) Theory and practice of mindfulness
    68→
    69→_Breathing as if your life depends on it._
    70→
    71→- **GOAL: Be Relaxed, Non Judgmental, and Alert at the same time.**
    72→- Meditation trains Attention(ability to concentrate), Meta-Attention(notice not paying attention).
    73→  - Like bike balancing. Constantly re-balancing so seems like rider always balanced.
    74→- Meditation is like exercise
    75→  - Work out, tough work out, much better then no workout.
    76→  - More you practice stronger you become.
    77→  - After a while, you just feel better and not sure why.
    78→- Intention - Intention == Affirmation == mental habit == good.
    79→- **Grandmother mind:** be gentle with yourself, the more you do it, the more of a habit it becomes.
    80→- Process Model:
    81→  - External Observer: Follow Breath, Distracted, Regain Focus
    82→- Dealing with distraction
    83→  - Experience without judging or reacting
    84→  - If you need to react, continue being mindful
    85→  - Let it go
    86→  - Sitting Time
    87→- Concepts I'm not summarizing
    88→  - Proper meditation posture
    89→  - Dude where is the science.
    90→  - Happiness default state of mind.
    91→
    92→### 3) Extend mindfulness beyond formal practice
    93→
    94→_Mindfulness without butt on cushion_
    95→
    96→- **Goal: Extend from formal to informal situations (rest to activity) and from self to others.**
    97→- Mindfulness in activity
    98→  - Will happen naturally from formal practice, but you can accelerate it.
    99→  - Imagine focusing on every meal as if it was prepared by a world class chef.
   100→  - Walking can be a formal "activity based" meditation.
   101→- Directing mindfulness on others. Informal/formal practice of mindful listening/conversation.
   102→  - Focusing on others, give them your full, non-judgmental attention.
   103→- Formal Practice of Mindful Listening
   104→  - Speaker: Speak for 3 uninterrupted minutes. You own them, even if silence.
   105→  - Listener: No speaking, acknowledge (maybe, but don't over acknowledge). If silence, be silent.
   106→  - Swap speaker.
   107→  - Meta conversation on process: How do you feel, anything you want to talk about.
   108→- Informal Practice of Mindful Listening
   109→  - Give the gift of your full attention.
   110→  - Because they're your close one, they deserve time and space to express themselves.
   111→  - When attention wanders, bring it back.
   112→- Mindful Conversation
   113→  - A. Mindful Listening
   114→  - B. Looping - close the loop, by repeating what you think you understood. Speaker works with you till fully understood.
   115→  - C. Dipping - We usually don't listen as we've wandered off. Dip into yourself
   116→    _ Listener - notice if you're being distracted, try to let it go.
   117→    _ Speaker - notice how this makes you feel, decide to talk about it, or let it go.
   118→- Formal Mindful Conversation
   119→  - Monologue 4 minutes: \* Listener: Pay attention, and periodically dip.
   120→  - Looping: 6 minutes to describe what i heard, and loop.
   121→  - Meta: 4 minutes meta conversation.
   122→- Informal Mindful Conversation
   123→  - Just like formal method, but you don't tell.
   124→  - Be sure to seek permission for looping - what you said sounds important, can I check what I understood?
   125→  - Consider explaining what you did, and let the other person join you.
   126→- Sustaining your practice
   127→  - Like exercise, only hard for first few months. Tips
   128→    1. Have a buddy ask: Am I doing it? Why is my life better? How did this conversation go?
   129→    1. Do less then you can
   130→    1. At a minimum, do a breathe/1 minute/2 minute.
   131→  - Keep the difficulty at just below what you can achieve - think of how video games work.
   132→- Lightness and Joy in Mediation
   133→  - Want a relaxed (light) focus on meditation. Try meditating on Joyful event.
   134→    - Bring full attention to something pleasant, holding kids hand, a nice meal, etc.
   135→  - Theory: This gain can be generalized to other practices, but still need formal meditation.
   136→  - Eventually Meditation causes - Sukha - non-energy expending joy.
   137→- Mastering focused and open attention:
   138→  - Focused attention - intense focus on chosen object.
   139→  - Open attention - let focus move to any incoming event without judgment.
   140→  - Values from circuits
   141→    - Requires Strong Meta Attention to stay on focus
   142→    - Strong clarity - analogy, strong torch light
   143→    - Relaxed Attention - needed so don't get exhausted from meditation.
   144→- Meditation Circuit Training (4x)
   145→  - 3 minute closed - keep focus on breath.
   146→  - 3 minutes open - allow focus to apply to each incoming thought
   147→- Stay motivated - you're going to suck till you don't
   148→- Walking Meditation
   149→  - Focus on walking while walking.
   150→  - Feel your feet touching the ground
   151→  - Don't take anything for granted.
   152→
   153→### 4) Self awareness leading to self confidence
   154→
   155→_All natural organic Self-Confidence_
   156→
   157→- **GOAL: Emotional Awareness -> Self Assessment -> Self Confidence**
   158→- Self Awareness - The basis of EI - Your internal state, preferences, resources, and intuitions.
   159→  - Emotional Awareness
   160→    - Resolution - See subtle differences between emotions.
   161→    - Vividness - Turn up the contrast, so we can see easily see the additional resolution.
   162→    - (Am Happy -> Feel Happy -> Experience Happy in my Body)
   163→    - The moment you observe an emotion, it's already less powerful.
   164→  - Accurate Self Assessment - Strengths and Weakness
   165→    - Essential for managers.
   166→    - We're not perfect, but how can we succeed despite these gaps.
   167→  - Self Confidence - Ego as big as Mt Fugi, or as small as grain of sand as needed.
   168→    - Ego gets in the way of listening, need to let it go to be open.
   169→    - Ego required when doing hard tasks like leading, need it to grow to take on the challenge
   170→    - You can admit weakness, without self-blaming
   171→    - Grandma Mind requires huge confidence
   172→- From Emotional Awareness to Self Confidence
   173→  - Emotional Awareness -> Self Assessment -> Self Confidence
   174→    - Engineers confident in systems when understand operational, failure, and error recovery behaviors.
   175→    - Understand operational, failure, and error recovery behaviors -> Self Assessment.
   176→    - Self Assessment has low SNR because of emotions . Boost Emotional Awareness -> Boost Self Assessment SNR
   177→  - Misc
   178→    - More we study ourselves, more objective we can become.
   179→    - We know all the skeletons in our closets, and can deal with them.
   180→    - Pep talk give transient boost, but it's NOT sustainable.
   181→- Body Scan 13m
   182→  - General
   183→    - Every time you scan, you build mental habit of polling your body.
   184→    - Attention, not sensation matters.
   185→    - SIY Body scan less intense then MBSR body scan.
   186→  - 1m Warm up mindful breathing
   187→  - 6m Scan Body 1 m per region, 6m total.
   188→    - Head - top, ears, back
   189→    - Face - Forehead, eyes, cheeks nose, lips, gums/tongue.
   190→    - Neck+Shoulders - neck, throat, shoulders
   191→    - Back - low, mid, upper back.
   192→    - Front - Chest and stomach
   193→    - Whole Body
   194→  - 2m Scan for Emotion - for an emotion, ok if none found.
   195→  - 3m Experience Positive Emotion - think of something awesome, and see how it feels in your body/face/shoulders/tension.
   196→  - 1m Cool Down mindful breathing.
   197→- Journalling For Self Assessment
   198→  - Journal
   199→    - Prompt, then free association on paper. (I use [750words](http://www.750words.com))
   200→    - Prompts to try:
   201→      - What I am feeling now
   202→      - I am aware that
   203→      - What motivates me is
   204→      - I am inspired by
   205→      - Today, I aspire to
   206→      - What hurts me is
   207→      - I wish
   208→      - Others are
   209→      - I made a happy mistake
   210→      - Love is
   211→  - 2m Positive Prime - Times when you did great, and are satisfied.
   212→  - 2m per Prompt/Free Associate - **1.** Things that give me pleasure are. **2.** My strengths are.
   213→  - 2m Negative Prime - Times when you responded negatively, where you weren't satisfied.
   214→  - 2m per Prompt/Free Associate - **1.** Things that annoy me are. **2.** My weaknesses are.
   215→- My emotions are not me.
   216→  - Emotions go from existential -> experiential -> physiological
   217→  - I am happy -> I feel happy -> I experience happy in my body
   218→
   219→### 5) Developing Self Mastery
   220→
   221→_Riding your emotions like a horse_
   222→
   223→- **GOAL: Compulsion -> Choice ([7H: Choose your response](/7h-c1))**
   224→- About Self Regulation
   225→  - Self-Control: Disruptive emotions under control
   226→  - Trustworthiness: Maintain honesty and integrity
   227→  - Conscientiousness: Responsibility for personal performance
   228→  - Adaptability: Flexibility in handling change
   229→  - Innovation: Being comfortable with novel ideas
   230→- NOT Avoiding or Suppressing Emotions
   231→  - It's about being skillful with emotions.
   232→  - Anger vs Indignation, anger powerless, but indignation a source of calm power.
   233→  - Negative emotions are at time appropriate, like for feeling empathy.
   234→- **Letting go WHILE STILL appreciating the ups and downs.**
   235→  - Emotions going to happen, BUT we have the power to let it go.
   236→  - PAIN is short, but SUFFERING is grasping and aversion.
   237→  - Grasping - holding on to something and not letting it go.
   238→  - _Wilting flowers don't cause suffering, it's the unrealistic desire for them to last forever._
   239→  - Aversion - avoiding something and refusing to think about it.
   240→  - _Pain doesn't cause suffering, it's the desire not to experience it that causes suffering._
   241→- Dealing with distress
   242→  - Know when you are not in pain - have a habit of enjoying when not in pain, this gives strength.
   243→  - Do not feel bad about feeling bad - (Meta distress) is not helpful, have grandmother mind on distress.
   244→  - Do not feed the [monsters](/monsters) - distress needs fuel, stop retelling the same story.
   245→    - Personal story - freak out over screwed up basement.
   246→    - When the same story becomes a persistent, repetitive thought loop, it becomes a psychic shadow requiring specialized banishment techniques: {%include summarize-page.html src="/psychic-shadows" %}
   247→  - Start every thought with kindness and humor - It's nicer that way, gives us reserve to deal with hardship.
   248→- Triggers - A small event results in an objectively too big response.
   249→  - Often have a repeated 'emotional' injury.
   250→  - Need to respond quickly in the moment (SBNRR), but do a SBNRR meditation afterwards to process and get better.
   251→  - More time you proactive long form, better you get in short form.
   252→- Identify triggers:
   253→  - Body - shallow breathing, rapid heartbeat, sick to stomach.
   254→  - Emotions - Amydala hijack, fight or flight, frozen
   255→  - Thoughts - Victim, blame, judgment, trouble focusing, outrage
   256→- **S**i**B**erinan **N**orthern **R**ail**R**oad:
   257→  - Stop, Breathe, Notice, Reflect, Respond.
   258→  - **Stop** is sacred, even for a few seconds. **Breathing** extends the pause.
   259→  - **Notice** to realize and calm the is a physiological response,
   260→    - I am angry -> I feel angry -> my body is experiencing anger.
   261→  - **Reflect** to calm the psychological response, and engage cognative process [cognative reframe].
   262→    - Every one wants to be happy, and act in a rationale way.
   263→  - **Respond** think of most helpful/appropriate response you can think of.
   264→    - Triggering the other person, will make situation escalate. Be calm.
   265→    - People will feel bad on own if needed.
   266→- Siberian northern railroad Meditation.
   267→  - 0.5m of mindful breathing: Warm up
   268→  - 2m: Priming/Focus negative emotions
   269→    - What was the emotion, the first emotion, where did you feel it, how do you feel now.
   270→    - Relive the negative emotion
   271→  - 0.5m: Stop/Breathe
   272→  - 1m: Notice and Experience
   273→  - 1m: Reflect on Origin
   274→  - 1m :Imagine Response
   275→  - 2m: Return to grounding: Tight fist, open to release emotion, 60s mindfulness breathing.
   276→- From self regulation to self confidence.
   277→  - Aversion operates by distracting. Instead of feeling vulnerable, we focus on other person being a dick.
   278→- Making Friends with emotions
   279→  - Blindly reacting to emotion or fighting hard, makes it worse.
   280→  - Instead, just observe, and reflect on the emotions, befriend them and they go away.
   281→  - See Getting to yes with yourself.
   282→
   283→### 6) Art of self motivation and building resilience
   284→
   285→_Making Profits, Rowing Across Oceans, and Changing The World_
   286→
   287→- **GOAL: Find your purpose then be resilliant to failure.**
   288→- Learn your **Purpose**, as you get good you hit **flow**, and then you get recognition and **pleasure**. See [post](/happy)
   289→  - Priority order: Satisfaction, Flow, and Pleasure.
   290→- Motivation: **Align** work with purpose. **Envision** future we desire. **Overcome** obstacles through resilience.
   291→- Alignment - Work is _meaningful_ for you, you frequently hit _flow_.
   292→- Flow - focused attention. Meditation helps.
   293→- Autonomy, Mastery, Purpose
   294→  - Pink's candle attach candle to wall experiment
   295→  - AMP provides creativity, rewards do not.
   296→  - Give employees why and outcome, let them figure out the how.
   297→- Know and align yourself
   298→  - Mindfulness -> Self Awareness -> You can figure out the opportunities to AMP.
   299→  - Abstract concepts, need to verbalize or write down to find them.
   300→  - [7H: Personal mission statement, funeral exercise.](/7h-c2)
   301→- Discovering values and higher purpose
   302→  - Prompts: My core values are, I stand for.
   303→  - Alone: Journal
   304→  - Group Mindful Listening: Speaker describes, group mindful listening, then free discussion afterwards to clarify.
   305→  - End meta.
   306→- Envisioning: Begin with the end in mind.
   307→  - Visualize it makes it much easier.
   308→  - Doing your mission exhausting at first (discovering your values) then energizing (figuring out how to achieve it).
   309→  - Prompt: If everything goes well, what will I be doing in 5 years.
   310→    - Who are you and what are you doing
   311→    - How do you feel
   312→    - What do people say about you
   313→    - Open mindfulness for a minute
   314→  - Write for 7 minutes.
   315→- Alternate Envisioning:
   316→  - You're at your own Obituary
   317→  - You're at a talk that is deeply touching and inspiring.
   318→    - What did the speaker saying why is it touching you.
   319→    - What makes you look up to the speaker, what do you envy.
   320→    - Imagine the speaker is you.
   321→- Share your ideal future LOTS. Because: 1) Inspire you. 2) Find Allies
   322→  - More you talk, more real it becomes for you, more you flesh it out.
   323→  - **People want to be inspired**
   324→  - People want to help.
   325→  - Sharing with others, will inspire others, and some will help.
   326→- Resilience - ability to remove obstacles, and return to baseline when troubles.
   327→  - Inner Calm - Foundation of optimism and resilience
   328→  - Emotional Resilience - Success/Failure are emotional experiences, build this, and can always celebrate progress.
   329→  - Cognitive Resiliece - How to explain setbacks to ourselves and others, to develop optimism.
   330→  - **Leaders provide this service to their organization and teams**
   331→- Inner calm
   332→  - Day to day things go wrong, but have a deep well of calmness, and can always return to it.
   333→  - Mindfulness key training.
   334→- Emotional Resilience
   335→  - Success/Failure emotional experiences -> Grasping/Aversion
   336→- Resilience Meditation
   337→  - Aversion is an emotion in the body. Get used to it, invite it as a friend.
   338→  - 3 deep breaths to calm the mind.
   339→  - Focus on breathing
   340→  - Quick Body Scan
   341→  - 4m - Experience failure - observe emotions/body
   342→  - Recall these are physiological experiences in the body, not you. Get used to feeling aversion.
   343→  - 30s pause.
   344→  - 4m - Experience success - observe emotions/body
   345→  - Recall these are physiological experiences in the body, not you. Get used to not feeling grasping.
   346→  - Back to mindfulness
   347→- Cognitive Resilience
   348→  - Success is 99% failure.
   349→  - You'll suck until you don't
   350→  - Best explorers lost most of the time'.'
   351→  - Bill gates/Brinn have no idea where they are going till they land it.
   352→  - Optimists: Setbacks are temporary and circumstantial. Overcome by effort and activity, how to overcome.
   353→  - Pessimists: Setbacks make me helpless, I am a failure . Thinks nothing can be done, gives up.
   354→  - Default, negative emotion 3:1 ratio.
   355→  - Imagine you get 2$ for every 1$ lost. Objective HUGE win, but subjective feel like a loser.
   356→  - **Realize you have a huge negative bias.**
   357→- Reducing cognitive negative bias -> Becoming an optimist
   358→  - Don't worry you'll overdue this, your negative bias so string, you'll be lucky if you get to objective.
   359→  - Focus on positive - gratefulness journal.
   360→  - Become objective and transform thinking on Success/Failure:
   361→    - How does your body feel?
   362→    - What story are you telling yourself?
   363→    - Positive, notice if you're downplaying, and take credit
   364→    - Negative, notice you're uplaying:
   365→      - Find evidence temporary.
   366→      - Feeling inadequate, focus on past success.
   367→
   368→### 7) Developing Empathy by connecting to others
   369→
   370→_Empathy and the Monkey business of brain tangos_
   371→
   372→- Empathy is feeling how others feel.
   373→- How to increase empathy
   374→  - Kindness Up => Empathy Up.
   375→  - Similarity Up => Empathy Up.
   376→  - What we think, We Become (why affirmations work)
   377→  - See people and think "they're just like me", and "I want to be kind to them".
   378→- Like me/Loving kindness practice
   379→  - Think about the person is like you (to do record script)
   380→  - Think about the person want loving kindness (todo record script)
   381→- When you get in a fight, go off in corner and do sameness/loving kindness meditation.
   382→- Traditional practice of loving kindness
   383→  - 2M: May I be well, May I be happy, May I be free from suffering
   384→  - 2M: Neutral Person: Be well, Be happy, Be free from suffering
   385→  - 2M: Negative Person: Be well, Be happy, Be free from suffering
   386→- Start with Sincerity, Kindness and Openness
   387→  - Easy for emotional brain to think someone is "bad"
   388→  - Easy for your cognitive brain to see someone is good, but hard to convince your emotions.
   389→- When a new relationship, or things go south
   390→  1. Give people benefit of the doubt.
   391→  1. Trust begins with Trust
   392→- When chairing a meeting: some assumptions
   393→  1. Everyone here to serve a greater good, till proven otherwise
   394→  1. Thus assume, None of us have hidden agendas, until proven otherwise.
   395→  1. Thus assume, Reasonable, even when disagree, until proven otherwise.
   396→- Empathic Listening:
   397→  - Mindful Listening. BUT: answer "I heard you feel", instead of "I heard you say".
   398→  - Prompts:
   399→    - A difficult work situation,
   400→    - Time when you felt pain, but couldn't do anything,
   401→    - Other emotional juice.
   402→- Strengthening empathic listening:
   403→  1. Mindfulness: makes us more perceptive
   404→  1. Kindness: lets us listen better to feeling
   405→  1. Curiosity: wonder at what people might be experiences
   406→  1. Practice: Causes more of mindfulness, kindness, curiosity.
   407→- Informal practice of empathic listening
   408→  - Harder: people don't like to hear 'I hear you feeling ...'
   409→  - PRIME: Mindful Breathing, Loving Kindness/Like Me,
   410→  - START: Remind to be curious, give lots of time.
   411→  - If possible ask how they feel.
   412→  - Interesting you say that, listening to you, I'm hearing....
   413→  - END: Make lots of time to listen and give them lots of air time.
   414→  - META: Was this conversation helpful to you?
   415→- **Political Awareness:** Empathy at the organization level, instead of personal level.
   416→- Political awareness practices:
   417→  - Empathy practices, but on steroids.
   418→  - Have a cross organization network of people you care about and trust and nurture them.
   419→  - Read the currents: How are decisions made? Authority/Consensus? Who is influencer?
   420→  - Distinguish: Your/Team/Organization's interests.
   421→  - Use Self awareness to understand your role.
   422→  - Use Empathic listening to undresatnd how people feel about situation and each other.
   423→- **Political awareness exercise**:
   424→  - Journal, or tell a friend
   425→  - PRIME: Think of a big, real conflict with lots of potency to you.
   426→  - Describe the situation as if you're right for 3m.
   427→  - Describe the situation as if other person right for 3m.
   428→  - Meta conversation.
   429→- Good news
   430→  - Empathy is feeling what other feels. Better Self Awareness, Better Empathy.
   431→  - XRef: Trust is basis of Mentoring
   432→  - XRef: Lack of Trust basis of 5 dysfunctions of a team.
   433→  - Kindness is a sustainable source of happiness
   434→- Not summarized
   435→  - Empathy, the brain and monkey business
   436→  - Praising people for working hard, not for being smart.
   437→    - TODO: Get Sean/Ammon's help on these.
   438→    - Your super power is someone can bring you a rough story, and you will make it great.
   439→    - NOT:Your super power is you're a great story teller.
   440→
   441→### 8) Leadership and Social Skills
   442→
   443→_Being Effective and Loved at the same time_
   444→
   445→- Lead with compassion, influence with goodness, communicate with goodness.
   446→- **Mantra: Love them. Understand them. Forgive Them. Grow with them.**
   447→- Most effective commanders are liked by their crews.
   448→- Talking about personal stuff, helps both of you build empathy.
   449→- Using Kindness to grow friendship from an ugly situation
   450→  - When something goes wrong, you can usually help each other, and through that build respect, trust and friendship.
   451→- Compassion: Mental state with concern for suffering of others and aspiration to see suffering relieved.
   452→  - Cognitive Compassion - I understand you
   453→  - Emotional Component - I feel for you
   454→  - Motivational Component - I want to help you.
   455→- Compassionate leadership is the most effective leadership
   456→  - Go from "I" to "We" to unlock the team. I is personal ego and doesn't allow others to participate and engage.
   457→  - Good to Great best business book ever, Defines Level 5 leaders.
   458→  - L5 leaders highly ambitious, but focused on greater good.
   459→    - Removes the self, and thus, allows others to inspire and contribute.
   460→    - Compassion (I understand you) and (I feel for you), remove the I, and (I want to help you) causes greater good.
   461→- Training compassion by multiplying goodness
   462→  - Build mental habits - more you think about it, more often you do it.
   463→  - Compassion mental habit is goodness.
   464→  - Use visualization to help us, since visualizing it helps.
   465→- Multiply Goodness Meditation
   466→  - Visualize breathing in goodness, it multiplying 10 fold, breathing out goodness.
   467→  - 2M pause
   468→  - Visualize each in breath bringing in goodness, it multiplying 10x in heart, breath out and white light expands
   469→  - 2m pause
   470→  - Visualize goodness in those we know. Visualize goodness radiating from their bodies, when you breathe in, bring it int o your heart.
   471→  - 2m pause
   472→  - Visualize goodness in everyone on the planet, breathe in all the goodness into your heart.
   473→  - 2m pause
   474→  - 1m mindfulness
   475→- Why multiply goodness works - it trains
   476→
   477→  - Seeing goodness in others - Builds (I understand you, and feel for you)
   478→  - Giving goodness to all - Builds I want to help you.
   479→  - Confidence that you can do it - Become comfortable doing it more and more.
   480→
   481→- Compassion Training For the brave - Tonglen:
   482→  - Advanced practice, come back when you've mastered more exercises.
   483→  - Like multiplying goodness, but you breathe in suffering, transform it to suffering, and radiate it out.
   484→  - Dali Lama main practice
   485→  - Trains you that you can transform suffering into goodness.
   486→  - Powerful since teaches you you can avoid aversion because you can remove suffering.
   487→- Influencing with goodness
   488→  - Already influencing, GOAL: Expand, and use it for good of all.
   489→  - People want to minimize danger (HUGE energy) , maximize reward (small energy).
   490→  - Negative Interaction have huge impact, vs Positive Interactions have small impact.
   491→  - Marriage needs 5:1 positive to negative to avoid divorce.
   492→- The SCARF MODEL for social brain
   493→  - **Status:** Where am I in the pecking order
   494→    - **BUILD:** Give credit, and feedback, ups peoples status
   495→    - Predicts longevity
   496→    - Threats triggered very easily
   497→    - Feel good about our status by compare ourselves to former self improving.
   498→  - **Certainty:** Do I know what what's going on.
   499→    - **Build:** removing ambiguity, and giving people certainly on things that matter.
   500→    - Uncertainty causes rumination, and can be debilitating
   501→    - Worried about your job, can't do anything cuz sucks up all brain power.
   502→  - **Autonomy:** Do I have control over the situation?
   503→    - **Build:** making clear it's people's choice, not yours.
   504→    - Not having control causes the stress, not the "experience".
   505→  - **Relatedness:** Is other person friend or foe.
   506→    - **Build:** by taking time to know people.
   507→    - Easy to make friends by saying hi, shaking hands, etc.
   508→  - **Fairness:**
   509→    - **Build:** making clear that you're being fair.
   510→    - Voluntarily injure themselves to fight injustice.
   511→    - Doesn't make sense but happens - see ultimatim experiment.
   512→    - Never underestimate sense of fairness, causes people self sacrifice.
   513→- Expand your influence
   514→  - Know you have influence
   515→  - Build confidence (removes ego) in lets you do this.
   516→  - Understand people and help them succeed -
   517→- How goodness can change a man's life in 10 minutes

   524→    - Content: What happened?
   525→      - Be as objective as possible
   526→    - Feeling: What emotions are involved (see SCARF)?

   531→    - Is it to make them feel bad? Or to learn something?

   533→    - I and You have different perspectives, focus on what a third party will see.
   534→    - Best way to find a common ground.

   598→### Working with suffering
   599→
   600→When suffering, you need to get to the cognative reframes, but first you need to be able to focus clearly, this requires calming the mind and experiences the pain (and first joy) to handle the reframes.
   601→

   603→

   608→- Some days harder then others
   609→- Some days impossible, just need to wait
   610→- Train in non
   611→- pain makes it easier, like gym.
   612→

   614→
   615→- Pain in Body
   616→- Tension
   617→- Pit in stomach

   619→- Nausia
   620→- Be willing to experience the pain in the body

   623→

   649→

   651→- Second, I see hole, and walk in.
   652→  - The hardest day
   653→  - You see the hole, but can't stop yourself as don't know how
   654→- Third, I see the hole, and I avoid it
   655→  - Build the ability to fix the problem, to walk around the hole.
   656→

   658→

   660→
   661→Dive training requires handling and practicing each failure mode.
   662→
   663→New divers can handle 1 problem, and then frequently abort their dive.
   664→Experienced diver can probably handle 2 or 3 then abort
   665→Pro divers can handle several combinations of problems.

     1→# Content Guidelines by Post Type
     2→
     3→## Core Consistency Rules
     4→
     5→### Style Consistency Principle
     6→
     7→**If you choose to deviate from the recommended style gu...
 
     1→# Content Guidelines by Post Type
     2→
     3→## Core Consistency Rules
     4→
     5→### Style Consistency Principle
     6→
     7→**If you choose to deviate from the recommended style guidelines below, maintain that deviation consistently throughout the entire piece.** Mixing styles within a single post creates jarring reader experiences.
     8→
     9→**Examples of acceptable consistent deviations:**
    10→
    11→- Using "we" throughout an entire post (but never mixing "we" and "I")
    12→- Writing in third person for a specific piece (but maintaining it throughout)
    13→- Using formal academic tone for technical content (but not switching to conversational mid-post)
    14→- Adopting a specific narrative voice for storytelling posts
    15→
    16→### Inconsistency Warnings
    17→
    18→**AI assistants and editors should flag these inconsistencies:**
    19→
    20→- ❌ Switching between "I" and "we" within the same post
    21→- ❌ Mixing formal and conversational tones randomly
    22→- ❌ Starting personal then becoming impersonal
    23→- ❌ Inconsistent use of headers, bullet styles, or formatting
    24→- ❌ Switching between metaphorical frameworks mid-post
    25→- ❌ Changing target audience assumptions (expert → beginner → expert)
    26→
    27→**The goal:** Readers should feel like they're having one coherent conversation, not multiple conversations stitched together.
    28→
    29→---
    30→
    31→## Universal Writing Style (All Content)
    32→
    33→### Voice and Perspective
    34→
    35→- **Always use "I"** for personal perspective, never "we"
    36→- **Direct and concise** - avoid flowery language where it obscures meaning
    37→- **Personal but pragmatic** tone
    38→- **Conversational vulnerability** - write like you're having coffee with a thoughtful friend who shares real struggles
    39→- **Vulnerable but authoritative** - show uncertainty alongside expertise
    40→- **Systems thinking approach** - naturally build frameworks and structured approaches
    41→- **Metaphorical thinking** - use consistent metaphors (dragons, mountains, rivers) to explain complex concepts
    42→
    43→### Language Patterns
    44→
    45→- **Questions to engage readers** and introduce new sections
    46→- **Concrete examples** over abstract concepts
    47→- **"Here's what I learned"** rather than "You should do this"
    48→- **Strategic use of rich metaphors** when they enhance understanding
    49→- **Self-deprecating humor** with phrases like "completely aspirational" and acknowledgment of personal flaws
    50→- **Vulnerability as strength** - openly discussing fears, failures, and contradictions
    51→- **Research integration** - heavy citing of books, studies, and external sources
    52→- **Avoid marketing speak and buzzwords** - no "revolutionary," "game-changing," or corporate jargon
    53→
    54→### Avoiding AI Writing Patterns
    55→
    56→**These patterns make writing feel generic and machine-generated. Avoid them:**
    57→
    58→_Reference: [Wikipedia: Signs of AI Writing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Signs_of_AI_writing)_
    59→
    60→**❌ Undue emphasis phrases:**
    61→
    62→- "stands as", "serves as", "plays a vital role in"
    63→- "underscores its significance", "highlights the importance"
    64→- "captivates both X and Y alike"
    65→- Instead: Be direct and specific about what something does or means
    66→
    67→**❌ Promotional/tourism language:**
    68→
    69→- "nestled within the breathtaking", "rich cultural heritage"
    70→- "must-visit", "hidden gem", "boasts a wide array"
    71→- Instead: Use concrete, sensory details and personal experience
    72→
    73→**❌ Editorializing phrases:**
    74→
    75→- "it's important to note that", "it's worth mentioning"
    76→- "notably", "importantly", "significantly"
    77→- Instead: Just state the point directly - if it's in your post, it's already important
    78→
    79→**❌ Superficial -ing phrase overuse:**
    80→
    81→- "highlighting the fact that", "showcasing the importance"
    82→- "demonstrating the value of", "emphasizing the need for"
    83→- Instead: Use active verbs and direct statements
    84→
    85→**❌ Formulaic conjunctions:**
    86→
    87→- Starting many sentences with "Additionally", "Furthermore", "Moreover"
    88→- Essay-like synthesis language that sounds academic rather than conversational
    89→- Instead: Use natural transitions and vary sentence structure
    90→
    91→**❌ Vague intensifiers:**
    92→
    93→- "very unique", "extremely important", "highly significant"
    94→- "truly remarkable", "particularly noteworthy"
    95→- Instead: Show don't tell - use specific examples that demonstrate importance
    96→
    97→**✅ Better approaches:**
    98→
    99→- Use specific numbers, names, and details over vague descriptions
   100→- Write like you're explaining to a friend, not composing an essay
   101→- Let the content speak for itself rather than emphasizing its importance
   102→- Replace abstract analysis with concrete observations
   103→- Use plain, direct language over formal academic phrasing
   104→
   105→### Structure Elements
   106→
   107→- **Extensive use of headers** for easy scanning
   108→- **Bullet points** to chunk information
   109→- **Table of contents** for longer pieces (auto-generated via vim-markdown-toc)
   110→- **Heavy cross-referencing** using `{% include summarize-page.html %}` for internal linking
   111→- **Progressive disclosure** - start with simple concepts, then drill deeper
   112→- **Iterative development** - posts evolve over time with update notes
   113→- **Framework building** - most posts end with practical application methods
   114→
   115→### Engagement Techniques
   116→
   117→- **Rhetorical questions** as section breaks
   118→- **Direct reader address** ("I bet you don't either")
   119→- **Dialog format** for internal conflicts and decision-making (real and imagined conversations)
   120→- **Real-time authenticity** - admit uncertainty and show work in progress
   121→- **Meta-commentary** on your own writing and thinking process
   122→- **Personal anecdotes as teaching tools** - stories that illustrate broader principles
   123→- **Pre-mortem/scenario planning** - regular use of "what if" thinking
   124→
   125→---
   126→
   127→## Content Type Guidelines
   128→
   129→### 1. Book Summaries/Reviews
   130→
   131→**Purpose:** Process learning and share insights from books that shaped your thinking
   132→
   133→**Structure:**
   134→
   135→- Always include book cover image and Amazon affiliate link
   136→- Use chapter-by-chapter breakdown for systematic books
   137→- Include "Why this book matters" section
   138→- End with "How this applies to you" practical takeaways
   139→
   140→**Voice:** Analytical teacher - "Here's what I learned and how you can apply it"
   141→
   142→**Key Elements:**
   143→
   144→- Heavy use of structured outlines and bullet points
   145→- Personal application examples throughout
   146→- Quote key passages that resonated
   147→- Connect to your existing frameworks and other books
   148→
   149→**Length:** 300-600 lines typically
   150→
   151→**Tags:** `book-notes`, plus relevant topic tags
   152→
   153→### 2. Personal Philosophy/Identity Posts
   154→
   155→**Purpose:** Work through fundamental life questions while creating frameworks others can use
   156→
   157→**Structure:**
   158→
   159→- Start with personal stakes - why this matters to you
   160→- Use creative metaphors consistently throughout (dragons, circles, etc.)
   161→- Include both emotional and logical analysis
   162→- Create memorable frameworks with clear components
   163→
   164→**Voice:** Vulnerable philosopher - "Here's how I think about life"
   165→
   166→**Key Elements:**
   167→
   168→- **Dialog format** for internal conflicts ("Dragon:" conversations)
   169→- **Extensive personal anecdotes** as proof points
   170→- **Alert boxes** for important caveats
   171→- **Visual elements** (images, diagrams) to break up text
   172→- **Cross-references** to related life frameworks
   173→
   174→**Length:** 400-1000+ lines for major pieces
   175→
   176→**Tags:** `how igor ticks`, plus relevant topics
   177→
   178→### 3. Professional/Management Content
   179→
   180→**Purpose:** Share hard-won workplace wisdom and practical frameworks
   181→
   182→**Structure:**
   183→
   184→- Start with the problem/challenge
   185→- Provide systematic framework or approach
   186→- Include specific workplace examples
   187→- Link to deeper reference materials
   188→- Include "what doesn't work" sections
   189→
   190→**Voice:** Experienced practitioner - "Here's what works in practice"
   191→
   192→**Key Elements:**
   193→
   194→- **Tactical advice** with concrete steps
   195→- **War stories** from actual management experience
   196→- **References to "Igor's book of..."** deeper materials
   197→- **Quantified examples** where possible
   198→- **Team scenarios** and people stories
   199→
   200→**Length:** 150-300 lines typically
   201→
   202→**Tags:** `manager`, `software engineering`, `emotional intelligence`
   203→
   204→### 4. Reference/Framework Content
   205→
   206→**Purpose:** Create comprehensive, living documents for personal and public use
   207→
   208→**Structure:**
   209→
   210→- Comprehensive table of contents
   211→- Clear section headers for easy navigation
   212→- "Quick reference" sections for immediate use
   213→- Update logs showing evolution over time
   214→
   215→**Voice:** Systematic organizer - "Here's a complete framework"
   216→
   217→**Key Elements:**
   218→
   219→- **Heavy cross-linking** between related concepts
   220→- **Actionable sections** with specific steps
   221→- **Examples and scenarios** for each major point
   222→- **Regular updates** with new insights
   223→- **Multiple entry points** for different use cases
   224→
   225→**Length:** 500-1000+ lines for comprehensive guides
   226→
   227→**Tags:** `framework`, `reference`, plus topic-specific tags
   228→
   229→### 5. Major Life Decision Documentation
   230→
   231→**Purpose:** Work through significant choices while creating reusable decision-making frameworks
   232→
   233→**Structure:**
   234→
   235→- Establish stakes and timeline
   236→- Map out all considerations systematically
   237→- Use creative metaphors to explore emotional aspects
   238→- Document decision-making process in real-time
   239→- Include uncertainty and evolution of thinking
   240→
   241→**Voice:** Thoughtful decision-maker - "Here's how I'm working through this"
   242→
   243→**Key Elements:**
   244→
   245→- **Real-time processing** with timestamps
   246→- **Both rational and emotional analysis**
   247→- **Creative frameworks** (dragons, councils, etc.)
   248→- **Progress tracking** and milestone documentation
   249→- **Honest uncertainty** and course corrections
   250→
   251→**Length:** 700+ lines for major decisions
   252→
   253→**Tags:** `decision-making`, plus relevant life area tags
   254→
   255→### 6. Practical Hobby/Lifestyle Posts
   256→
   257→**Purpose:** Share what works in daily life - products, approaches, systems
   258→
   259→**Structure:**
   260→
   261→- Problem or need statement
   262→- Solution overview
   263→- Specific recommendations with reasoning
   264→- Personal experience and results
   265→- Alternative options and trade-offs
   266→
   267→**Voice:** Helpful enthusiast - "Here's what works for me"
   268→
   269→**Key Elements:**
   270→
   271→- **Product links** and specific model numbers
   272→- **Personal experience** with timeline
   273→- **Comparison with alternatives**
   274→- **Practical setup tips**
   275→- **Cost/benefit analysis**
   276→
   277→**Length:** 50-200 lines typically
   278→
   279→**Tags:** `toys`, `biking`, `health`, plus specific categories
   280→
   281→### 7. Journal/Exploration Content
   282→
   283→**Purpose:** Think through emerging topics and capture evolving insights
   284→
   285→**Structure:**
   286→
   287→- Date-based entries showing progression
   288→- Stream-of-consciousness exploration
   289→- Questions and uncertainties
   290→- Links to related reading/research
   291→- Periodic synthesis and pattern identification
   292→
   293→**Voice:** Curious explorer - "Here's what I'm figuring out"
   294→
   295→**Key Elements:**
   296→
   297→- **Experimental thinking** without predetermined conclusions
   298→- **Question collections** and research notes
   299→- **Pattern recognition** across different inputs
   300→- **Regular synthesis** attempts
   301→- **Links to external sources** and influences
   302→
   303→**Length:** Variable, grows over time
   304→
   305→**Tags:** `exploration`, `journal`, plus topic tags
   306→
   307→### 8. Personal Narrative/Story Posts
   308→
   309→**Purpose:** Use personal stories and experiences as teaching tools to illustrate broader principles
   310→
   311→**Structure:**
   312→
   313→- Set scene with personal context
   314→- Develop story with specific details and dialogue
   315→- Extract universal principles or lessons
   316→- Connect to broader frameworks or life philosophy
   317→- Invite reader reflection or application
   318→
   319→**Voice:** Reflective storyteller - "Here's what this experience taught me"
   320→
   321→**Key Elements:**
   322→
   323→- **AI conversations** with Tony (life coach) showing real-time processing
   324→- **Family adventures and moments** that illustrate larger principles
   325→- **Life transition narratives** about major changes and decisions
   326→- **Identity conflict stories** (bike vs car, work vs family, etc.)
   327→- **Dialogue format** showing internal or external conversations
   328→- **Specific sensory details** that make stories vivid and memorable
   329→
   330→**Length:** 200-800 lines typically
   331→
   332→**Tags:** `story`, `narrative`, plus relevant life area tags
   333→
   334→---
   335→
   336→## Content Development Workflow
   337→
   338→### 1. Start with Purpose
   339→
   340→- **Personal processing** - What am I trying to figure out?
   341→- **Public value** - How can this help others?
   342→- **Framework building** - What systematic approach am I developing?
   343→
   344→### 2. Choose Content Type
   345→
   346→- Match your purpose to the appropriate content type above
   347→- Consider hybrid approaches for complex topics
   348→- Plan for potential evolution (exploration → framework → published advice)
   349→
   350→### 3. Apply Type-Specific Guidelines
   351→
   352→- Use the voice and structure patterns for your chosen type
   353→- Include all key elements relevant to that content type
   354→- Follow the suggested length guidelines
   355→
   356→### 4. Cross-Link and Connect
   357→
   358→- Reference related content throughout
   359→- Build connections between different frameworks
   360→- Update existing content with new insights
   361→
   362→### 5. Tag and Organize
   363→
   364→- Use consistent tagging system
   365→- Include type-specific tags plus topic tags
   366→- Consider searchability and future discovery
   367→
   368→---
   369→
   370→## Special Considerations
   371→
   372→### Dual-Purpose Content
   373→
   374→Most substantial content should serve both personal processing AND public teaching. This is your superpower - turning personal work into valuable public content.
   375→
   376→### Living Documents
   377→
   378→Many pieces should be treated as living documents that get updated over time with new insights, examples, and refinements.
   379→
   380→### Authentic Vulnerability
   381→
   382→Your willingness to show uncertainty, mistakes, and work-in-progress thinking is what makes the content uniquely valuable. Maintain this across all content types.
   383→
   384→### Framework Thinking
   385→
   386→You naturally build systematic approaches to complex topics. Lean into this strength by making frameworks explicit and reusable.
   387→
   388→### Meta-Awareness
   389→
   390→Your ability to comment on your own thinking process adds depth and authenticity. Include this meta-commentary where it serves the content.
   391→
   392→---
   393→
   394→## Technical Implementation Guide
   395→
   396→### Alert Boxes
   397→
   398→Use alert boxes to highlight important information, warnings, or construction notices:
   399→
   400→**Syntax:**
   401→
   402→```liquid
   403→{% include alert.html content="Your message here" style="info" %}
   404→{% include alert.html content="Warning or caution message" style="warning" %}
   405→{% include alert.html content="Work in progress notice" style="danger" %}
   406→```
   407→
   408→**Common use cases:**
   409→
   410→- Construction/work-in-progress notices
   411→- Important caveats or disclaimers
   412→- Cross-references to related content
   413→- Privilege acknowledgments
   414→
   415→**Example:**
   416→
   417→```liquid
   418→{% include alert.html content="🚧 Construction Zone 🚧 This post is in heavy progress! 🔨 Check back later for updates ⏳" style="warning" %}
   419→```
   420→
   421→### URL Redirects
   422→
   423→Set up redirects for shorter, memorable URLs using both `redirect_from` and `alias`:
   424→
   425→**Syntax:**
   426→
   427→```yaml
   428→redirect_from:
   429→  - /shortname
   430→  - /abbreviation
   431→alias:
   432→  - /shortname
   433→  - /abbreviation
   434→```
   435→
   436→**Example:**
   437→
   438→```yaml
   439→redirect_from:
   440→  - /7habits
   441→  - /7h
   442→alias:
   443→  - /7habits
   444→  - /7h
   445→```

   447→### Book Links and Amazon Affiliate Integration
   448→
   449→Use the Amazon include for book references with ASIN numbers:
   450→
   451→**Syntax:**
   452→
   453→```liquid
   454→{% include amazon.html asin="ASIN_NUMBER" %}
   455→{% include amazon.html asin="ASIN1;ASIN2;ASIN3" %}
   456→```
   457→
   458→**Examples:**
   459→
   460→```liquid
   461→{% include amazon.html asin="0071499938" %}
   462→{% include amazon.html asin="B07LDSPRYM;B00506CSDQ;B07C66Z4M4" %}
   463→```
   464→
   465→**How it works:**
   466→
   467→- ASINs are looked up in `_data/asins.json` for title, image, and description
   468→- Automatically includes affiliate tag (`ighe-20`)
   469→- Falls back to generic Amazon image if product data not available
   470→- Supports multiple books separated by semicolons
   471→- Images are styled consistently with fallback text if images fail to load
   472→
   473→**Best practices:**
   474→
   475→- Use ASIN numbers (found in Amazon URLs) rather than direct links
   476→- Group related books together in single include
   477→- Place near relevant text sections
   478→- ASIN data is managed automatically via scripts in `/scripts/` directory

   530→- Providing deeper dive options

   542→### Matrix Visualizations
   543→
   544→#### Quadrant Matrix (2x2 Grid)
   545→
   546→Use the quadrant-matrix include for any 2x2 grid visualizations like personality types, decision matrices, or prioritization frameworks:
   547→
   548→**Syntax:**
   549→
   550→```liquid
   551→{% include quadrant-matrix.html
   552→    title="Main Title"
   553→    subtitle="Optional subtitle"
   554→    x_label="X Axis Label →"
   555→    y_label="Y Axis Label →"
   556→    q1_name="TOP-RIGHT NAME"
   557→    q1_subtitle="Optional subtitle"
   558→    q1_traits="Line 1<br>Line 2<br>Line 3"
   559→    q1_color="rgba(255, 224, 224, 0.5)"
   560→    q2_name="TOP-LEFT NAME"
   561→    q2_subtitle="Optional subtitle"
   562→    q2_traits="Description here"
   563→    q2_color="rgba(230, 230, 250, 0.5)"
   564→    q3_name="BOTTOM-LEFT NAME"
   565→    q3_subtitle="Optional subtitle"
   566→    q3_traits="Description here"
   567→    q3_color="rgba(232, 244, 234, 0.5)"
   568→    q4_name="BOTTOM-RIGHT NAME"
   569→    q4_subtitle="Optional subtitle"
   570→    q4_traits="Description here"
   571→    q4_color="rgba(255, 229, 180, 0.5)"
   572→%}
   573→```
   574→
   575→**Parameters:**
   576→
   577→- `title`, `subtitle`: Main headings for the matrix
   578→- `x_label`, `y_label`: Axis labels with directional arrows
   579→- `q1-q4`: Quadrants numbered clockwise from top-right
   580→  - `q#_name`: Main heading in quadrant
   581→  - `q#_subtitle`: Optional subtitle
   582→  - `q#_traits`: Description (use `<br>` for line breaks)
   583→  - `q#_color`: Background color (hex or rgba)
   584→
   585→**Common use cases:**
   586→
   587→- **PANAS Personality Types**: Mad Scientist, Cheerleader, Judge, Poet
   588→- **Eisenhower Matrix**: Urgent/Important task prioritization
   589→- **Risk Assessment**: Probability/Impact matrix
   590→- **SWOT Analysis**: Strengths/Weaknesses/Opportunities/Threats
   591→- **Energy Management**: High/Low energy vs High/Low focus
   592→
   593→**Example - PANAS Personality Types:**
   594→
   595→```liquid
   596→{% include quadrant-matrix.html
   597→    title="Arthur Brooks' PANAS Personality Types"
   598→    subtitle="Based on the Positive and Negative Affect Schedule"
   599→    x_label="Positive Affect →"
   600→    y_label="Negative Affect →"
   601→    q1_name="MAD SCIENTIST"
   602→    q1_subtitle="Creative Intensity"
   603→    q1_traits="Feels deeply<br>Passionate<br>Ride the waves"
   604→    q1_color="rgba(255, 224, 224, 0.5)"
   605→    q2_name="JUDGE"
   606→    q2_subtitle="Critical Thinker"
   607→    q2_traits="Spots problems<br>High standards<br>Practice gratitude"
   608→    q2_color="rgba(230, 230, 250, 0.5)"
   609→    q3_name="POET"
   610→    q3_subtitle="Calm Observer"
   611→    q3_traits="Steady emotions<br>Zen-like presence<br>Cultivate excitement"
   612→    q3_color="rgba(232, 244, 234, 0.5)"
   613→    q4_name="CHEERLEADER"
   614→    q4_subtitle="Natural Optimist"
   615→    q4_traits="Spreads joy<br>Sees bright side<br>Watch for warnings"
   616→    q4_color="rgba(255, 229, 180, 0.5)"
   617→%}
   618→```
   619→
   620→#### Six-Cell Matrix (2x3 Grid)
   621→
   622→Use the six-cell-matrix include for 2x3 grid visualizations (2 rows × 3 columns). Perfect for models like Influencer 2.0 that have 6 distinct dimensions:
   623→
   624→**Syntax:**
   625→
   626→```liquid
   627→{% include six-cell-matrix.html
   628→    title="Main Title"
   629→    subtitle="Optional subtitle"
   630→    row1_label="Top Row Label"
   631→    row2_label="Bottom Row Label"
   632→    col1_label="Left Column"
   633→    col2_label="Middle Column"
   634→    col3_label="Right Column"
   635→    c1_name="Cell 1 (Top-Left)" c1_subtitle="Subtitle" c1_traits="Description<br>Line 2" c1_color="rgba(232,244,234,0.5)"
   636→    c2_name="Cell 2 (Top-Middle)" c2_subtitle="Subtitle" c2_traits="Description" c2_color="rgba(255,229,180,0.5)"
   637→    c3_name="Cell 3 (Top-Right)" c3_subtitle="Subtitle" c3_traits="Description" c3_color="rgba(255,224,224,0.5)"
   638→    c4_name="Cell 4 (Bottom-Left)" c4_subtitle="Subtitle" c4_traits="Description" c4_color="rgba(230,230,250,0.5)"
   639→    c5_name="Cell 5 (Bottom-Middle)" c5_subtitle="Subtitle" c5_traits="Description" c5_color="rgba(220,245,245,0.5)"
   640→    c6_name="Cell 6 (Bottom-Right)" c6_subtitle="Subtitle" c6_traits="Description" c6_color="rgba(255,240,220,0.5)"
   641→%}
   642→```
   643→
   644→**Parameters:**
   645→
   646→- `title`, `subtitle`: Main headings for the matrix
   647→- `row1_label`, `row2_label`: Labels for the two rows
   648→- `col1_label`, `col2_label`, `col3_label`: Labels for the three columns
   649→- `c1-c6`: Cells numbered left-to-right, top-to-bottom
   650→  - `c#_name`: Main heading in cell
   651→  - `c#_subtitle`: Optional subtitle
   652→  - `c#_traits`: Description (use `<br>` for line breaks)
   653→  - `c#_color`: Background color (hex or rgba)
   654→
   655→**Common use cases:**
   656→
   657→- **Influencer 2.0**: Motivation/Ability × Personal/Social/Structural
   658→- **Project Management**: High/Low priority × Planning/Execution/Review stages
   659→- **Skills Development**: Learn/Practice × Technical/Social/Strategic
   660→- **Any 2×3 framework**: Two categories with three levels each
   661→
   662→**Example - Influencer 2.0:**
   663→
   664→```liquid
   665→{% include six-cell-matrix.html
   666→    title="Influencer 2.0: Six Sources of Influence"
   667→    subtitle="Change happens when you influence across all dimensions"
   668→    row1_label="Motivation"
   669→    row2_label="Ability"
   670→    col1_label="Personal"
   671→    col2_label="Social"
   672→    col3_label="Structural"
   673→    c1_name="Personal Motivation"
   674→    c1_subtitle="Self-Regulation"
   675→    c1_traits="Connect to values<br>Build intrinsic motivation"
   676→    c1_color="rgba(232, 244, 234, 0.5)"
   677→    c2_name="Social Motivation"
   678→    c2_subtitle="Peer Influence"
   679→    c2_traits="Harness peer pressure<br>Build accountability"
   680→    c2_color="rgba(255, 229, 180, 0.5)"
   681→    c3_name="Structural Motivation"
   682→    c3_subtitle="Incentives"
   683→    c3_traits="Design reward systems<br>Align incentives"
   684→    c3_color="rgba(255, 224, 224, 0.5)"
   685→    c4_name="Personal Ability"
   686→    c4_subtitle="Skills"
   687→    c4_traits="Build individual skills<br>Provide training"
   688→    c4_color="rgba(230, 230, 250, 0.5)"
   689→    c5_name="Social Ability"
   690→    c5_subtitle="Support"

   692→    c5_color="rgba(220, 245, 245, 0.5)"

   694→    c6_subtitle="Environment"

   696→    c6_color="rgba(255, 240, 220, 0.5)"
   697→%}
   698→```

2025-10-15 12:56:09 
{
  "file_path": "/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/jung-self-ego.md",
  "content": "---\nlayout: post\ntitle: \"The Self vs Ego: Jung's Map for Living Authenti...
 
{
  "file_path": "/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/_d/jung-self-ego.md",
  "content": "---\nlayout: post\ntitle: \"The Self vs Ego: Jung's Map for Living Authentically\"\npermalink: /self-ego\nredirect_from:\n  - /jung-self\n  - /self-vs-ego\nalias:\n  - /jung-self\n  - /self-vs-ego\ntags:\n  - how igor ticks\n  - psychology\n  - identity\n  - emotional intelligence\n---\n\nI've spent most of my life building an impressive ego. Senior engineer at Meta. Dad of two. The guy who bikes everywhere and does magic tricks at parties. These aren't lies - they're real parts of who I am. But here's what I'm learning: when I'm living entirely for that r\u00e9sum\u00e9, when I'm performing my identity instead of living it, something feels hollow.\n\nCarl Jung had a framework for this tension that I keep coming back to. He distinguished between the Ego (the social self we present to the world) and the Self (the totality of who we are, including the parts we hide or don't know yet). The relationship between these two determines whether we're living authentically or just playing a role.\n\nThis isn't academic psychology for me. This is about the times I've chosen the impressive project over the meaningful one, the performative family moment over the genuine connection, the LinkedIn-worthy achievement over the thing that actually feeds my soul.\n\n<!-- prettier-ignore-start -->\n<!-- vim-markdown-toc-start -->\n\n- [What Ego and Self Actually Mean](#what-ego-and-self-actually-mean)\n  - [Ego: Your Social Operating System](#ego-your-social-operating-system)\n  - [Self: The Whole Truth](#self-the-whole-truth)\n- [The Four-Stage Cycle](#the-four-stage-cycle)\n  - [Stage 1: Ego Inflation - \"I Am My Achievements\"](#stage-1-ego-inflation---i-am-my-achievements)\n  - [Stage 2: Ego Deflation - When The Story Breaks](#stage-2-ego-deflation---when-the-story-breaks)\n  - [Stage 3: Dialogue with Self - Listening to What's Been Ignored](#stage-3-dialogue-with-self---listening-to-whats-been-ignored)\n  - [Stage 4: Integration - Ego in Service of Self](#stage-4-integration---ego-in-service-of-self)\n- [How This Shows Up in Real Life](#how-this-shows-up-in-real-life)\n  - [Signs You're Ego-Dominated](#signs-youre-ego-dominated)\n  - [Signs You're Connecting with Self](#signs-youre-connecting-with-self)\n- [Practices for the Shift](#practices-for-the-shift)\n- [The Paradox: Ego Isn't the Enemy](#the-paradox-ego-isnt-the-enemy)\n- [How This Connects to Everything Else](#how-this-connects-to-everything-else)\n\n<!-- vim-markdown-toc-end -->\n<!-- prettier-ignore-end -->\n\n## What Ego and Self Actually Mean\n\n### Ego: Your Social Operating System\n\nThe Ego is your conscious identity - the \"I\" that interacts with the world. It's built from:\n\n- **Your roles**: parent, engineer, partner, friend\n- **Your achievements**: promotions, degrees, projects shipped\n- **Your reputation**: how others see you, what they expect\n- **Your self-image**: the story you tell about who you are\n\nThe Ego isn't bad. It's necessary. You need it to function in society, to hold down a job, to maintain relationships. Without an Ego, you'd be like a ship without a rudder - no direction, no ability to navigate social waters.\n\nBut here's the trap: the Ego is designed to be loved, admired, and validated by others. When you over-identify with it, your whole sense of worth depends on external approval. You become the r\u00e9sum\u00e9, the LinkedIn profile, the performance.\n\nI see this in myself when I check how many likes a post got, when I angle for recognition in meetings, when I feel that little hit of validation from someone saying \"You're so productive!\" The Ego loves that stuff. And there's nothing wrong with enjoying it - until it becomes the only source of fuel.\n\n### Self: The Whole Truth\n\nThe Self is the totality of who you are - conscious and unconscious, light and shadow, socially acceptable and hidden away. It includes:\n\n- **The parts you show**: your public persona, your achievements\n- **The parts you hide**: your fears, your shame, your secret desires\n- **The parts you deny**: the anger you suppress, the grief you avoid\n- **The parts you don't know yet**: your unlived potential, your unexamined gifts\n\nJung saw the Self as the organizing principle of the psyche - the deep, authentic center that knows your true path even when your conscious mind is confused. Some people call it intuition, inner wisdom, or the \"still small voice.\"\n\nThe Self doesn't care about your LinkedIn profile. It cares about wholeness, authenticity, meaning. It's the voice that whispers \"This isn't right\" when you're in the wrong job, even if it's prestigious. It's the pull toward creative work that doesn't pay, toward the conversation that matters more than the networking opportunity.\n\nWhen I'm connected to my Self, I can feel it in my body. There's a sense of alignment, of rightness, even when the choice doesn't make external sense. Like when I chose to take [time off](/time-off) instead of chasing the next promotion, or when I decided to bike to work even though driving was more \"efficient.\"\n\n## The Four-Stage Cycle\n\nThe relationship between Ego and Self isn't static - it's a cycle you move through repeatedly at different levels throughout life. Understanding where you are in the cycle helps you know what you need.\n\n{% include quadrant-matrix.html\n    title=\"The Ego-Self Cycle\"\n    subtitle=\"The journey from performance to authenticity\"\n    x_label=\"Self Connection \u2192\"\n    y_label=\"Ego Strength \u2192\"\n    q1_name=\"4. INTEGRATION\"\n    q1_subtitle=\"Ego serves Self\"\n    q1_traits=\"Living authentically<br>Using roles consciously<br>Inner-directed action\"\n    q1_color=\"rgba(232,244,234,0.5)\"\n    q2_name=\"1. EGO INFLATION\"\n    q2_subtitle=\"I am my achievements\"\n    q2_traits=\"Over-identified with roles<br>External validation needed<br>Performing constantly\"\n    q2_color=\"rgba(255,224,224,0.5)\"\n    q3_name=\"2. EGO DEFLATION\"\n    q3_subtitle=\"The story breaks\"\n    q3_traits=\"Crisis or burnout<br>What felt solid crumbles<br>Dark night of the soul\"\n    q3_color=\"rgba(230,230,250,0.5)\"\n    q4_name=\"3. DIALOGUE\"\n    q4_subtitle=\"Listening within\"\n    q4_traits=\"Turning inward<br>Shadow work begins<br>Self demands attention\"\n    q4_color=\"rgba(255,229,180,0.5)\"\n%}\n\n### Stage 1: Ego Inflation - \"I Am My Achievements\"\n\nThis is where you're over-identified with your social self. You ARE your job, your role, your accomplishments. Your worth is tied to external markers of success.\n\n**What it feels like:**\n- \"If I'm not producing, I'm not valuable\"\n- Constant comparison to others\n- Can't stop achieving, proving, performing\n- Terrified of failure or criticism\n- Exhausted but can't slow down\n\n**Why it happens:**\nSociety rewards Ego inflation. You get promoted, praised, validated. The dopamine hits keep coming. So you keep feeding the Ego, building the r\u00e9sum\u00e9, collecting achievements.\n\n**My experience:**\nI spent years in this stage. My identity was \"productive person who ships things.\" I tracked everything, optimized everything, measured everything. I wrote about [treating life like a business](/life-as-business), which is peak Ego inflation - trying to systematize and control your way to worth.\n\nThe problem? It worked. Until it didn't. The more I achieved, the more I needed to achieve to feel okay. The treadmill kept speeding up.\n\n### Stage 2: Ego Deflation - When The Story Breaks\n\nSomething punctures the Ego's story. Could be burnout, failure, loss, or just a creeping sense that \"this can't be all there is.\" The identity you've built starts feeling like a cage.\n\n**What it feels like:**\n- Depression, anxiety, or numbness\n- \"What's the point of any of this?\"\n- Success feels hollow\n- Roles feel like prison\n- Nothing makes sense anymore\n\n**Common triggers:**\n- Mid-life crisis (classic for a reason)\n- Burnout from over-achievement\n- Major failure or rejection\n- Loss of a key role (job, relationship, health)\n- Simply running out of new achievements to chase\n\n**Why it's necessary:**\nThe Self is knocking. All those parts you ignored while building your impressive life? They're demanding attention. The Ego has to deflate so the Self can emerge.\n\n**My experience:**\nThis happens to me in smaller ways regularly - like realizing I'd stopped biking because it didn't fit my \"efficient Tesla driver\" identity. Or noticing I was writing blog posts for the metrics instead of because I had something to say.\n\nThe bigger deflations came during career transitions, when the role I'd built my identity around suddenly didn't fit anymore. That's terrifying. Who am I if I'm not \"that guy who does X\"?\n\n### Stage 3: Dialogue with Self - Listening to What's Been Ignored\n\nYou start turning inward. Listening to the parts of yourself that got exiled while you were busy performing. This is uncomfortable as hell because you meet your shadow - all the stuff you didn't want to be.\n\n**What it looks like:**\n- Therapy, coaching, deep introspection\n- Creative work with no external goal\n- Time in nature, meditation, solitude\n- Journaling, dream work, active imagination\n- Facing uncomfortable truths about yourself\n\n**What you discover:**\n- The anger you've been suppressing\n- The grief you've been avoiding\n- The desires you deemed \"unacceptable\"\n- The gifts you've been too scared to claim\n- The truth about what you actually want\n\n**Why it's generative:**\nThis is where real growth happens. Not growth as \"more achievements\" but growth as \"more whole.\" You reclaim the disowned parts. You integrate the shadow. You start distinguishing between what you actually want and what you think you should want.\n\n**My experience:**\nFor me, this looks like my [morning meditation](/siy) practice, where I actually sit with what I'm feeling instead of immediately problem-solving. It's the [750 words](/750-words) journaling where I write without editing. It's the conversations with my [AI life coach Tony](/bike-tesla-identity) where I work through contradictions instead of papering over them.\n\nIt's also my [time off](/time-off), where I deliberately step away from achievement mode to remember who I am underneath the productivity.\n\n### Stage 4: Integration - Ego in Service of Self\n\nThis is the goal: your Ego becomes a tool in service of your Self rather than your master. You use your roles consciously rather than being controlled by them. You can achieve without over-identifying with achievement.\n\n**What it feels like:**\n- Choices feel aligned, even if unconventional\n- Less reactive to praise or criticism\n- Can hold paradoxes (successful AND authentic, driven AND peaceful)\n- Energy comes from within, not just external validation\n- Comfortable with uncertainty\n\n**What changes:**\n- You still have roles, but you're not trapped by them\n- You still achieve, but it's not compulsive\n- You still care what others think, but it doesn't control you\n- You can be both ambitious and at peace\n\n**Why it's not permanent:**\nThis isn't a destination. You'll cycle back through ego inflation and deflation at deeper levels. Each time through, you integrate more of yourself, become more whole. It's a spiral, not a straight line.\n\n**My experience:**\nI taste this in moments: writing something because I need to say it, not because I think it'll perform well. Choosing to [coach](/coaching) someone when there's no career benefit. Taking the bike when the Tesla would be easier, because it feeds something in me that matters.\n\nIt's also in how I think about [regrets](/regrets) now - not as failures of my Ego but as data about my values, signs from my Self about what matters.\n\n## How This Shows Up in Real Life\n\n### Signs You're Ego-Dominated\n\n- **Compulsive achieving**: Can't stop producing, shipping, proving\n- **Validation addiction**: Constantly checking metrics, likes, approval\n- **Identity crisis from role changes**: Who am I without this job/relationship/status?\n- **Exhaustion**: Performing your identity is tiring\n- **Comparison**: Constantly measuring yourself against others\n- **Can't be alone**: Need external stimulation to feel okay\n- **Defensive**: Criticism feels like an attack on your existence\n- **Stuck in stories**: \"I'm the kind of person who...\" becomes a cage\n\n### Signs You're Connecting with Self\n\n- **Aligned choices**: Decisions feel right even if they don't make external sense\n- **Less reactive**: Praise and criticism are just data, not life-or-death\n- **Comfortable with paradox**: Can be both successful and searching, confident and uncertain\n- **Energy from within**: Not entirely dependent on external validation\n- **Okay with uncertainty**: Don't need to have it all figured out\n- **Can be alone**: Solitude is generative, not threatening\n- **Open to growth**: Criticism can be useful information\n- **Flexible identity**: Can try on different roles without losing yourself\n\n## Practices for the Shift\n\nMoving from Ego-dominance to Self-alignment isn't a one-time thing. It's a daily practice. Here's what helps me:\n\n**Solitude and reflection:**\n- Regular time alone without agenda or distraction\n- Morning meditation where I just sit with what is\n- Walks without podcasts or music\n- My [time off](/time-off) rituals of stepping away from achievement mode\n\n**Creative expression with no audience:**\n- Writing that never gets published\n- Magic practice just for the joy of it\n- Projects with no career benefit\n- Art that serves no purpose\n\n**Depth work:**\n- Therapy or [coaching](/coaching) that goes beyond problem-solving\n- Conversations that aren't networking\n- Books that challenge your worldview\n- [Journaling](/750-words) without editing\n\n**Notice what you're hiding:**\n- The anger you suppress\n- The desires you deem \"unacceptable\"\n- The parts of yourself you exile\n- The choices you make for image rather than truth\n\n**Body-based practices:**\n- [Mindfulness meditation](/siy) that keeps you present\n- Exercise that's not about achievement\n- Notice how choices feel in your body\n- Pay attention to what gives you energy vs what drains you\n\n**Work with your shadow:**\n- Notice what triggers you in others (often disowned parts of yourself)\n- Explore the \"unacceptable\" feelings (rage, jealousy, pettiness)\n- Reclaim the gifts you've been too scared to claim\n- Ask: what parts of me have I exiled to maintain this identity?\n\n## The Paradox: Ego Isn't the Enemy\n\nHere's what I keep learning: the goal isn't to destroy your Ego or transcend it. The goal is to right-size it.\n\nYou need an Ego to function. You need roles, identity, the ability to navigate social reality. The problem comes from over-identification - when you forget that the role is something you're playing rather than who you are.\n\n**Healthy Ego:**\n- Knows it's a tool, not the whole person\n- Serves the Self's deeper purpose\n- Can adapt and change as needed\n- Doesn't require constant validation\n- Can hold achievement lightly\n\n**Integration means:**\n- Let Self lead, Ego execute\n- Use social roles as vehicles for Self-expression, not prisons\n- Dance between individual authenticity and social connection\n- Be in the world but not entirely of it\n- Achieve without over-identifying with achievement\n\nI think about my [Tesla vs bike identity crisis](/bike-tesla-identity). My Ego wanted the story to be simple: \"I'm a car-free person\" or \"I'm a Tesla driver.\" But my Self knows it's both/and. Sometimes the bike serves what I need (connection to the body, mindfulness, adventure). Sometimes the Tesla serves what I need (family time, long trips, creative space).\n\nThe Ego wants a consistent story. The Self is comfortable with complexity.\n\n## How This Connects to Everything Else\n\nThis framework ties together so many things I've been working on:\n\n**Mindfulness and emotional intelligence:**\n{% include summarize-page.html src=\"/siy\" %}\n\nThe body scan and self-awareness practices in Search Inside Yourself are literally practices for distinguishing Ego from Self. \"I am angry\" (Ego identification) vs \"I feel anger in my body\" (Self observation).\n\n**Understanding your shadows and triggers:**\nThose [regrets](/regrets) you carry? Often they're your Self trying to tell you something your Ego doesn't want to hear. The regrets point to your values - what your Self actually cares about versus what your Ego thinks you should want.\n\n**Life transitions and identity shifts:**\nMy [bike vs Tesla](/bike-tesla-identity) story is a microcosm of the Ego-Self dynamic. The Ego wanted a fixed identity. The Self knew I needed flexibility.\n\n**The coaching mindset:**\nWhen I'm [coaching](/coaching) someone, I'm often helping them distinguish between Ego concerns (status, image, should) and Self concerns (meaning, alignment, truth). The breakthrough moments come when they stop defending their Ego and start listening to their Self.\n\n**Time off and rest:**\nMy [time off](/time-off) is literally scheduled Ego deflation - stepping away from achievement mode so I can hear what my Self actually needs.\n\n---\n\nThis is a framework I'm still learning. I catch myself in Ego inflation regularly - chasing metrics, performing my identity, needing validation. But now I notice it faster. I can ask: \"Is this serving my Ego or my Self?\" And sometimes, I can choose differently.\n\nThe work isn't to get it perfect. The work is to keep dancing between these two parts of yourself - the social self that navigates the world and the authentic self that knows your true path. When Ego serves Self instead of the other way around, that's when life starts feeling right.\n"
}

    18→I've spent most of my life building an impressive ego. Senior engineer at Meta. Dad of two. The guy who bikes everywhere and does magic tricks at parties.     21→

   396→### Alert Boxes
   397→
   398→Use alert boxes to highlight important information, warnings, or construction notices:
   399→
   400→**Syntax:**
   401→
   402→```liquid
   403→{% include alert.html content="Your message here" style="info" %}
   404→{% include alert.html content="Warning or caution message" style="warning" %}
   405→{% include alert.html content="Work in progress notice" style="danger" %}
   406→```
   407→
   408→**Common use cases:**
   409→
   410→- Construction/work-in-progress notices
   411→- Important caveats or disclaimers
   412→- Cross-references to related content
   413→- Privilege acknowledgments
   414→
   415→**Example:**
   416→
   417→```liquid
   418→{% include alert.html content="🚧 Construction Zone 🚧 This post is in heavy progress! 🔨 Check back later for updates ⏳" style="warning" %}
   419→```
   420→
   421→### URL Redirects
   422→

   424→

   426→
   427→```yaml
   428→redirect_from:
   429→  - /shortname
   430→  - /abbreviation
   431→alias:
   432→  - /shortname
   433→  - /abbreviation

{
  "file_path": "/Users/idvorkin/gits/blog/content_guidelines.md",
  "old_string": "## Technical Implementation Guide\n\n### Alert Boxes",
  "new_string": "## Technical Implementation Guide\n\n### Opening Paragraphs and Excerpts\n\n**CRITICAL: Always start posts with a plain text opening paragraph before any includes, alerts, or special formatting.**\n\n**Why this matters:**\n\nJekyll automatically generates excerpts (post summaries/previews) for blog indexes, RSS feeds, and social media sharing. The excerpt is typically the first paragraph or first ~150 words of your post. If you place an alert box, image, or other include immediately after the front matter, the excerpt will be broken or empty, resulting in:\n\n- \u274c Broken previews in blog index pages\n- \u274c Empty descriptions for social media shares\n- \u274c Missing summaries in RSS feeds\n- \u274c Poor SEO snippet previews\n\n**What excerpts are:**\n\nExcerpts are automatically extracted text snippets that represent your post in:\n- Blog homepage listing pages\n- Category/tag archive pages\n- RSS/Atom feed readers\n- Social media link previews (Twitter, LinkedIn, etc.)\n- Search engine result snippets\n\n**Correct structure:**\n\n```markdown\n---\ntitle: \"Post Title\"\npermalink: /url\n---\n\nYour compelling opening paragraph goes here. This should hook the reader and give them a clear sense of what the post is about. It should be plain text without any Jekyll includes, HTML, or special formatting.\n\n{% include alert.html content=\"Any alerts or notices go AFTER the opening paragraph\" style=\"warning\" %}\n\nRest of your content...\n```\n\n**Wrong structure:**\n\n```markdown\n---\ntitle: \"Post Title\"\npermalink: /url\n---\n\n{% include alert.html content=\"Alert immediately after front matter breaks excerpts!\" style=\"warning\" %}\n\nYour opening paragraph...\n```\n\n**Best practices:**\n- Make the opening paragraph 2-4 sentences\n- Hook the reader with a personal stake or compelling question\n- Give enough context that the excerpt works as a standalone preview\n- Keep it conversational and engaging\n- No includes, HTML tags, or special formatting in the first paragraph\n\n### Alert Boxes"
}

   390→Your ability to comment on your own thinking process adds depth and authenticity. Include this meta-commentary where it serves the content.
   391→
   392→---
   393→
   394→## Technical Implementation Guide
   395→
   396→### Opening Paragraphs and Excerpts
   397→
   398→**CRITICAL: Always start posts with a plain text opening paragraph before any includes, alerts, or special formatting.**
   399→
   400→**Why this matters:**
   401→
   402→Jekyll automatically generates excerpts (post summaries/previews) for blog indexes, RSS feeds, and social media sharing. The excerpt is typically the first paragraph or first ~150 words of your post. If you place an alert box, image, or other include immediately after the front matter, the excerpt will be broken or empty, resulting in:
   403→
   404→- ❌ Broken previews in blog index pages
   405→- ❌ Empty descriptions for social media shares
   406→- ❌ Missing summaries in RSS feeds
   407→- ❌ Poor SEO snippet previews
   408→
   409→**What excerpts are:**
   410→
   411→Excerpts are automatically extracted text snippets that represent your post in:
   412→- Blog homepage listing pages
   413→- Category/tag archive pages
   414→- RSS/Atom feed readers
   415→- Social media link previews (Twitter, LinkedIn, etc.)
   416→- Search engine result snippets
   417→
   418→**Correct structure:**
   419→
   420→```markdown
   421→---
   422→title: "Post Title"
   423→permalink: /url
   424→---
   425→
   426→Your compelling opening paragraph goes here. This should hook the reader and give them a clear sense of what the post is about. It should be plain text without any Jekyll includes, HTML, or special formatting.
   427→
   428→{% include alert.html content="Any alerts or notices go AFTER the opening paragraph" style="warning" %}
   429→
   430→Rest of your content...
   431→```
   432→
   433→**Wrong structure:**
   434→
   435→```markdown
   436→---
   437→title: "Post Title"
   438→permalink: /url
   439→---
   440→
   441→{% include alert.html content="Alert immediately after front matter breaks excerpts!" style="warning" %}
   442→
   443→Your opening paragraph...
   444→```
   445→
   446→**Best practices:**
   447→- Make the opening paragraph 2-4 sentences
   448→- Hook the reader with a personal stake or compelling question
   449→- Give enough context that the excerpt works as a standalone preview
   450→- Keep it conversational and engaging
   451→- No includes, HTML tags, or special formatting in the first paragraph
   452→
   453→### Alert Boxes
   454→
   455→Use alert boxes to highlight important information, warnings, or construction notices:
   456→
   457→**Syntax:**
